text: The next item is the debate on the Commission declaration on democracy and justice in Romania.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, fate has dictated that for the last 28 years, in some way or form, I have been a close follower of developments in Romania, and if you see the progress made over that period of time, you can only be astonished by the force of the Romanian people’s will to become a fully fledged European, democratic, open nation. This development was reflected in the recent report on the cooperation and verification mechanism (CVM) which the Commission published last week, where we had an overview of the progress of the CVM over the past decade. It was not a linear development: sometimes, elements went fast; sometimes they went a bit more slowly, but still the development was spectacular. We could say that Romania is now in the final leg of this long, long marathon, heading to a situation where development towards the strengthening of the rule of law is irreversible, and that is the criterion the Commission now applies. It should be irreversible and, in this context, what we have seen over the last couple of days is worrying. The emergency ordinance and the draft legislation pertaining to the fight against corruption cannot be interpreted as anything other than a step back from the progress we have seen in the last decade, and I would urgently call upon the Romanian Government to reconsider what they have done, both with the emergency ordinance and with the draft legislation. Like any European nation, the Romanian nation deserves politicians and governments who support the fight against corruption, who want to rid their societies completely of corruption. And the efforts made in Romania – I must underline this – have been phenomenal, with really very good progress. So, why would you, in the final metres of a marathon, turn back and go in the other direction? I would like to call upon the Government not to go down that road. And we have seen the protests in Romania. We have seen the very clear worries expressed by the Romanian judiciary on this. Let them finish their job so that we can then come to the conclusion that developments are irreversible. The Commission has a direct interest in all of this because the legislation, if it is adopted, could also affect the disbursement of European funds in Romania, so we have to be very careful that we assess that. We will analyse the draft legislation and look into these matters, but today, for me, the most important thing is to make this political point to the Romanian Government: do not turn your back on this development. Do not go the other way. Continue. Hold this course, however painful it might sometimes be, because you do it in the service of your population. All Romanians deserve a country freed of corruption. And look at what has been achieved! Do not ever forget that. Let me end by referring to someone whom I regard as one of the biggest, most important Romanians of the 20th century. Sadly he has been dead for quite some time, but for me he reflects the European spirit of that great nation. It is Paul Celan. He was a Romanian who spoke German. He was a Jew, who lived in exile in Paris. He was thus a true European, not by choice but by fate because first the Nazi persecution then the Communist oppression prevented him from staying in his native land. But he remained a European, living in Paris, writing his poetry in German even in the 1940s, and believing in this European dream of European brotherhood. And he was a true son of the Romanian nation. Romania needs to take its place amid the European nations without being seen as in any way different. To achieve its dream it also needs to rid itself of corruption. It is almost there: the development is almost irreversible. So please, I say to the Romanian Government: do not take any steps in the other direction.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, as Vice-President Timmermans has just said, we are concerned about the decisions that the Romanian Government is taking. 29 days after taking office, his priorities are to weaken the fight against corruption and lower prison sentences for the corrupt. The Attorney General, the General Council of the Magistracy and even the President of the Republic have asked to correct these two excesses and the Romanian Government does not listen to them. Citizens are demonstrating in the streets across the country and the Romanian government is also ignoring them. Let no one be confused. The problem is not whether or not we like the laws passed by the government of a Member State. The problem is whether these laws weaken the quality of democracy, the quality of justice, the quality of the rule of law. And that is what we are discussing this morning. Nothing more, but nothing less. We debate with full respect for the institutional political sovereignty of Romania but, at the same time, with full responsibility. Because this Parliament also represents the twenty million Romanians. The voice of Romanians has the same right to be heard in the Parliament of Strasbourg or in the Parliament of Brussels as in the Parliament of Bucharest. Ladies and gentlemen, on days like today it should be remembered that belonging to the European Union is not just about receiving funds and sharing borders. It is to assume a series of principles and values ​​and, above all, the commitment to maintain them in the future. It is to assume that in Europe, in Europe, no one is above the law and to ensure that justice is exactly the same for everyone. It is to assume that crimes never go unpunished and that it is mandatory to prosecute and bring them to court. A government can have a parliamentary majority, but that does not mean that it is not wrong, that does not mean that it can do anything. In the rule of law, the force of the law has limits in the constitutional values ​​that justify our coexistence. In the rule of law, the law cannot be unfair. In the rule of law, the law cannot be a Trojan horse against democracy. You cannot govern so that there are first and second class citizens or citizens who have to comply with the law and others who can live outside the law. The action of the new Romanian Government - as Mr Timmermans has said - is destroying years and years of the fight against corruption, promoting impunity. And abusive behavior can set Romania back. This is an alert that is lit in the European Parliament. The Romanian Government still has time to rectify, and we formally ask it from the European Parliament to rectify it. Things in a democracy cannot be done in any way and when you make a mistake you have to know how to rectify it. No government in the world is above the law. The laws belong to the people and when the government acts against the people it loses the title that allows it to call itself a democratic government. To rule for corruption is to rule against democracy.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mister President! For the S&D Group, today's debate marks the beginning of a careful and constructive examination of what is going on in Romania. The rule of law and the principle of the separation of powers are for us immovable principles; they are of universal importance and must apply to all Member States. Wherever these principles are violated, we must oppose them. We take this debate very seriously and the situation does not tolerate any party political squabbles; therefore this debate must be followed by a detailed discussion in the LIBE committee, which includes an information visit to Romania. We must not allow ourselves to be seduced by superficial politics of the day: we have to go deep. All facts must be on the table and all actors must be scrutinized. The scourge of corruption can only be eradicated if the analysis is ruthlessly applied. We need to talk about the role of the institutions and how they fulfill their obligations, about the prison system and how corruption crimes are dealt with, about the principle of proportionality and the importance of prevention, and also about the role of the secret services in fighting corruption. In our opinion, they have no business there. The main aim is to strengthen the independence of the judiciary, law enforcement and the judiciary. We will address these questions in the LIBE committee emphatically, relentlessly and with the political will not to change daily political change. The point is to improve the situation in Romania and to do what the Vice-President has just said, namely to successfully cover the last few meters.

name: Monica Macovei
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, two nights ago, the Romanian Socialist Government amended, by emergency ordinance, the Criminal Code and the Code of Criminal Procedure. The amendments to the Code of Criminal Procedure and Procedure were published around one o'clock at night in the Official Gazette. Do you know what are the headlines in the Romanian press? This government is called the government of thieves, the mafia installed in the government, the organized crime group, the government of bandits. Of course, because they acted at night, unexpectedly, without notifying anyone, without being on the agenda, and they amended the Criminal and Criminal Procedure Code to get rid of them, to get rid, first of all, of the party president. Socialist from Romania, Mr. Dragnea, who has a two-year sentence for electoral fraud and who risks another one now, but escaped the file because, through these ordinances - this was the urgency: emergency ordinances - Dragnea, the president The Socialist Party of Romania can no longer be tried in the second case because it abrogated this crime, it no longer exists. So to change the abuse of office, the abuse of power that exists in all countries of this world, as a result of which many politicians escape, many from the administration, many from the Socialist Party and ALDE who are together in government. Do you know that the world is on the street? One week ago, there were a hundred thousand people in Bucharest, on Sunday, just to prevent the adoption overnight, so that the bandits could then adopt these emergency ordinances. And last night there were about two hundred thousand people on the street in Bucharest and another two hundred thousand people, at least, all over the country, almost half a million people took to the streets and will go out every day in the street. The only thing Parliament can and must do, and the Commission, is to ask that by 9 February, when the amendments to the Criminal Code enter into force, it ask this government to repeal everything by emergency ordinance that emergency ordinance that amended the Criminal Code.That's it, no mission.What to check on the mission?After what happened and when nothing can come back?Now go on a mission tomorrow if you want!Go to the people, be with the Romanian people, with the Romanian people and not with the thieves!And I would say something else: it was just announced yesterday that a new blow is coming on Friday: they want to abolish the National Anticorruption Directorate, they want to stop being investigated.So, go to Romania, but tomorrow, not after February 9, when the amendments to the Criminal Code come into force, if you are really correct with Romania and the Romanians!(The speaker agreed to answer a question referred in accordance with the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Ioan Mircea Paşcu (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Madam, as you surely know, last night the anti-corruption prosecutors were ordered to initiate penal investigations against the officials and civil servants who dared to draw up draft legislation perceived as a curtailment of their absolute power. Is that not a perfect example of anti-corruption being abused?

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: Answer to a question addressed in accordance with the "blue card" procedure.- Thank you very much for the question, Mr Pascu.This is exactly what must happen: thieves must be investigated.In Romania, thieves must be investigated and have been investigated, which is why we entered the European Union with the fight against corruption, with the red flag, which the socialists also left.Isn't it normal to investigate them?Not to mention that, also through that emergency ordinance, given at night, you do not change the Criminal Code at night, at midnight, unless you are a thief.By that ordinance, they amended the Criminal Code to get rid of what they were doing that night.They have taken away the criminal's favor, for example.Exactly what they did, because there are over two thousand cases from which criminals escape.Criminals need to be investigated, of course.

name: Norica Nicolai
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, no one can question the European vocation of the Romanian people. How can no one question the political option expressed in December, which led to a PSD-ALDE government. In fact, today in Bucharest, Commissioner, we are witnessing, under the pretext of the administration of justice, an attempt to overthrow a legitimately elected political power. Because this ordinance, Commissioner, is made in accordance with the provisions of the Romanian Constitution, which obliges, when the Constitutional Court declares unconstitutional texts of law, to be brought in accordance with that law within 45 days. By the way, a minister of justice from the previous government said that in Romania human rights are a luxury. Yes, Mr President, I am a luxury because this Constitutional Court has enshrined the fact that abuses are being made regarding the right of defense, that there are interceptions without a warrant from the judge, that abuse of office is too broad an incrimination to procedural guarantees is not respected. The Romanian state is motivated to fight corruption and has proved it, but the battle of corruption does not mean in any case selective justice, abusive justice. Justice must be equal for all and, therefore, I welcome the fact that we will have a very clear investigation of what is happening in Romania and not an emotional manipulation. I understand, Mr President, that Romania is a credible partner and a credible member of the European Union. I would not want, for the Romanian people, to question this credibility today under a purely political pretext. Including DNA, the main institution that claims to be a defender of corruption today, was established by emergency ordinance. We cannot, Mr President, in the name of a battle that is fair, that is legitimate, with dishonest means, change a political power.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, tens of thousands of Romanian citizens have been taking to the streets for days to protest against two decree laws prepared by the premier which decriminalize corruption offenses below a certain damage threshold. I sympathize with their battle and with the reaction of President Iohannis, who spoke of the decrees as a day of mourning. Coming from Italy, I know what he means when he talks about mourning. In Italy there have been many attempts to decriminalize corruption and even complicity with the mafia in the Berlusconi years. I can assure you that the corruption has been strengthened. Above all, I find the way in which the emergency decrees were passed: secretly, at night, without first consulting Parliament and the Constitutional Court. This is a frequent way of proceeding in Europe: executive power is increasingly centralized and the political forces that win the elections behave as if this victory allowed the abolition of the check and balance mechanisms on which constitutional democracies are founded. The protests of citizens and the press in Romania remind us that they too - associations and the press - are powers called to restrain central power, especially in times of economic and social crisis. The Romanian government says that decriminalization is necessary to avoid the overcrowded prisons, denounced by the European Court of Human Rights. It's an excuse that doesn't stand up. The argument has also been used in Italy. Similar decrees are adopted to avoid imprisonment for a few dozen corrupt politicians. It is all here. What citizens, NGOs, constitutional judges, the president himself, in Romania denounce, in my humble opinion, rightly. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question asked under the "blue card" procedure.- Dear colleague, you talked about two ordinances: do you know the real situation in Romania?Do you know that these are not two ordinances?Do you know that the pardon order is sent to Parliament in the form of a law?And the second question: if the president of your country were to incite the population by going to an unauthorized rally - he is a mediator, not an instigator - and would refuse to declassify some documents related to the joint SRI and justice team investigations, would you consider interference in justice?Because our judicial experts, professional associations, consider interference in justice.

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL)
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- I will not go into the details, I know that they are two decrees and I only invite you not to speak of interference from justice because this is also a language I know, which we have all heard in Italy.When political corruption expands, those responsible for corruption typically say that there is interference from justice.I invite you to just be careful.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group.- The massive demonstrations in Bucharest last night and the days before show that the Romanians take their democracy very seriously.This morning I read that the Minister of Commerce wants to give up his position because he does not want to take these proposals on his behalf.I also see this debate as a support for the plea to rethink matters.It should convey a sense of urgency to the Romanian government because corruption is the rottenness in the system.It erodes trust in the rule of law and also the trust between you and the neighbors.When that happens, you are very far from home.Commissioner Timmermans rightly said: Romania is on the right track, the last few meters.Why is this happening now?I appreciate your very clear statements.I propose to work together because we have seen with Hungary and Poland what happens if we are not on time.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE).
text: – Mr President, it is important that we are having this debate. We must speak out against corruption everywhere, and today we are here because we hear the people of Romania and we stand with them. The EU institutions, and this Parliament in particular, cannot remain silent on political corruption if we are to remain relevant to the people we represent. Let me be clear. This is not about the Romanian nation or the Romanian people: this is about the corrupt few who are working to circumvent the law. Romania’s efforts to join the European Union, 10 years ago, were pushed by those who wanted a different way, who believed in Europe and its value system, and who looked to Europe as a way to ensure that a crooked establishment never again gripped the reins of power. Europe cannot and should not abandon those who are reaffirming these ideas in the streets of Bucharest and Timișoara. And this is an issue that goes beyond Romania. I come from Malta, where our Government has the dubious honour of having the only sitting EU Minister, and now the EU Energy Council Chair, whose secret financial set-ups were exposed by the Panama Papers. So, as you can imagine, Vice-President Timmermans, the fight against corruption is top of people’s concerns, at home too. Strong anti-corruption policies must be a hallmark of our European Union. This is about standing up for our founding principles. People across the Union look to the EU institutions for leadership and direction in the fight against corruption. They cannot be met with silence, indifference or excuses. So my message here today: Români, suntem cu voi! (Vorbitorul a acceptat să răspundă unei întrebări adresate în conformitate cu procedura „cartonașului albastru” (articolul 162 alineatul (8) din Regulamentul de procedură)).

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: Question asked under the "blue card" procedure.- Dear colleague, I respect you very much and my question for you is if you think you are informed and documented necessary and correctly about what is happening in Romania or if you have taken, without an analysis, practically, the explanations and arguments of Romanian colleagues fromyour delegation?

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Listening to the people in this room today and looking at all the young people protesting on the streets of Romania, knowing many Romanian people, who have spoken to me – and even, yes, looking at the message that was just sent by the highest authorities in Romania to all the email addresses of those working in this Parliament – yes, I know what is happening in Romania, and I am more convinced than ever of what I have just said.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Mr First Vice-President of the European Commission, beyond the tragic-comic speech of my colleague Macovei, around the amendments to the Criminal Code adopted by the government, it is clear that the street in Romania is trying to cancel the December 11 elections. In recent years, abuses, violations of the law, the accentuation of the abusive and repressive character of the state have intensified. The commission was silent on the magistrates' strike, although it had information about the situation. He was silent when he learned about secret protocols between DNA and SRI, although he should have investigated. This must be done by the LIBE Commission in Romania and here in Parliament. This country, deeply loyal, Romania, deserves to return to democracy, the constitution and the separation of powers in the state. At this dramatic moment for my country, the country would not accept, my nation would not accept the street to overthrow a government and the consequences would be incalculable; and I remind the European Commission, in 2012, that the Commission's complicity or the voluptuousness with which Basescu's theses were embraced led to the cancellation of the 2012 referendum. It would be tragic and unacceptable for this to happen again.

name: Mircea Diaconu (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, in order for the discussion to be complete, you also had to have a criminal from Romania here. And that's me. I was investigated while I was a senator and minister of culture. I was investigated for two years. At each visit to the General Prosecutor's Office, the press was announced, it was natural for the press to be announced, my public destruction was, of course, attempted. Two years later, the prosecutor investigating me said the following: "Mr. Deacon, I have not found any damage, but I am sending you to court." I think he smiled cynically, as a kind of personal victory, and sent me to court asking for two and a half years in prison for me, with execution. I was acquitted, of course, after another two years. I don't want to talk about my years of torment and how much I lost and probably got older during this time. This is not the problem. The problem is that in Romania it is, indeed, an enormous problem, but not where you discuss it, where you see it, some of you, but in the fact that, for some time now, the popular vote has been modified, stolen, thrown away. and simply by methods other than democratic ones. I won't go into details, it's not time. Commissioner, with all due respect, I have all the respect for you, without question, I do not agree with you at all on one point, namely that of admiration for Paul Celan. I think the same. The problem is different: let, in my opinion and according to my request, let Romania find its way, alone, it has all the institutions at hand, there is justice and it is functional, there is a Constitutional Court that will resolve this dispute in a short time. It is democracy in Romania. The moment people go out on the street, nothing happens and they can take their step, there is justice in Romania the moment this dispute will be settled in court.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE).
text: - Mr President, 300,000 Romanians took to the streets last night in Bucharest and other cities in Romania and Europe alone to protest against criminal policy measures that offer politicians a defense against justice. But, first of all, we must say that it is not a problem of Romania and the image of Romania must not be affected. Hundreds of thousands of Romanians protesting peacefully, sanctioning the government's interested criminal policy, show that Romanian society has taken it before politicians. Most Romanians, President Klaus Iohannis, civil society, the institutions of the judiciary are fighting with all legal and constitutional weapons to stop this abuse of government. It is not the street that seeks to overthrow a legitimate government, but the ruling politicians, the ruling party leaders believe that if they win the election, politicians are not given the responsibility to rule by law, but the privilege of being above the law that governs the country. question mark the functioning of the rule of law. The Social Democratic Party around which this government is formed has launched an aggressive election campaign for populist measures, social actions focused on promises to increase revenues without budgetary substantiation and has never spoken about these changes in criminal law that are at the center of concerns this government since the beginning of its term. We call on the European Commission and the European Parliament to support the efforts of Romanian citizens, to support the efforts of the President of Romania, the efforts of the institutions of the judiciary and to take all legal and possible steps to determine and persuade the Romanian government to withdraw and cancel these amendments to the Criminal Code. Code of Criminal Procedure. What is happening in Romania is not a struggle of Romanians against Romanians, it is a struggle of Romanian society with some of the political leaders who do not understand that in a country of the European Union the law cannot be changed at will.The speaker refused to answer a question put by Doru-Claudian Frunzulică under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 162 (8)), arguing that it was a ploy by the Socialist colleagues to take as much as possible.more the word to defend a wrong project).

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: - Mister President! What was actually decided in Romania? First: Up to a maximum damage amount of 45,000 EUR, abuse of office should no longer lead to a prison sentence. Rather, the amount must be reimbursed and a fine is also payable. It is criticized that a complainant is first needed for the investigation. Second: There is a penalty for minor offenses, for the seriously ill and for mothers with young children. In view of the conditions in Romanian prisons, this is certainly a good decision for the latter. In order to improve these conditions in the long term, of course, completely different measures are required. And one can certainly also discuss why an urgent procedure was decided. I am very grateful that, at the request of the Social Democrats, this process is not just being addressed casually today, but that critical questions can be specifically followed up in the responsible committee and as part of a so-called mission. (The speaker declined to answer a question from Mr Rübig about the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the Constitutional Court has found that some provisions of the Criminal Code were unconstitutional. As a result, the PSD-ALDE government issued an emergency ordinance to regulate this. The same thing was previously used by the Cioloș government and the Boc government. The government of President Iohannis, the Cioloș government, made one hundred and fifty-one amendments, made in secret without any public consultation. Why, Commissioner, did you not say then that Romania has taken a step back? Moreover, a series of changes made by the Cioloș government fundamentally violated human rights, for example, the prosecutor was given the right to change the judge's decision, although justice is done by the judge. These constitutional changes have not been the subject of any public scandal, have not been sanctioned and have not been drawn to attention by the Commission, and now it is a disguised action to overthrow the legitimate government of Romania and not to take into account the Romanian vote of December . Mrs. Macovei, you have stuck an unfair and untrue label on Romania. That's how you advocated the referendum and the MCV. That is why the Romanians do not vote for you and I do not agree with your opinions. Yes, be with us, those who will not violate the most democratic way of expression, the vote of Romanians!

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, in Romania the street does not demand a change of government as Mrs Dăncilă and Mr Bostinaru said, but the withdrawal of ordinances.Such a decision is needed, otherwise European funds will be lost.Commissioner Timmermans made it very clear.But not only the money is at stake, but also the country's honor.It was even shown by a minister in the socialist government who has just resigned."I cannot accept imposture or lies," said this minister from the Romanian Socialist Party.I therefore call on the European Socialists to reflect on this gesture, their solidarity with self-amnestied corruptions is unacceptable.I suggest them not to forget that the Romanians overthrew Ceaușescu in 1989 and I am convinced that they are able to put Dragnea in his place, and his place is not at the head of the Romanian Parliament, it is elsewhere.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I am addressing first of all my colleagues from the right-wing MEPs and I want to tell you once again that Romanians, through culture, history, traditions, are clearly a European people and have a European vocation. I want to ask them: why don't we lean more towards dialogue, towards cooperation, towards partnership? Why do we always turn to international bodies, the so-called "High Gates"? Why don't we try to collaborate more between us Romanians? Because only together we could, in the end, achieve a stronger, more respected Romania, a Romania that would play a more important role in the European Union. Why do we always fail to collaborate and why do we always split into two or more camps? Why is there a fracture in Romanian society? Why don't we show those European values ​​that we always invoke? There is only one solution: collaboration between Romanians for Romania's progress.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, I have been following the counter-calls of my Romanian counterparts in the Chamber since yesterday, and this proves that the situation in this country is certainly very tense. Respect for the rule of law is a cornerstone of every Member State of the European Union. It is clear from the debate that everyone agrees that we need to monitor the situation in Romania closely. We support the struggle of the Romanian people who are mobilizing en masse to crack down on corruption, which of course is not unique to Romania but also to other Member States of the European Union. Corruption is certainly not struck either by the decriminalization of embezzlement offenses of less than EUR 200 000, or by the release of corrupt politicians, or, of course, by the release of criminals on the grounds that there is an overcrowding. in prisons. It is certain that this legislation must be revoked, which was passed on an emergency basis.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this debate calls our attention to one of the most serious problems today in the European Union: the promiscuity between the political and the judicial, between the political and the judicial. The democratic rule of law will only be democratic if it is of law and will only be of law if it is democratic. This implies separation of powers, implies that the judicial investigation does not take place according to the political opportunity, means that the policy does not take advantage of the judicial investigations. Politics cannot be judicialized, just as justice cannot be politicized. The rule of law is a state that is guided by its concrete actions by law and the ones who say the law are the courts, not the secret services or any other institutions of a political or administrative nature. Criminal investigation cannot be used for political purposes, just as criminal investigation cannot be carried out for political purposes. You cannot manipulate the judiciary, nor can you manipulate political power.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the judicial system in Romania has not worked well in recent years. The rule of law has always been on shaky feet, with countless concrete examples. Suffice it to say that the country’s biggest secret service scandal since ’89, which is briefly about the home affairs service, seems to have directly influenced the work of prosecutors and courts, used the judiciary for political struggles and showdowns. So the situation has not been as good so far as many thought from abroad. It is enough to think only of the minority issue. But the current changes are a decade-long step backwards. The intention of the governing parties is clear: to save the political and economic elite under process from the clutches of the judiciary. And the citizens perceive this exactly, but two months after the election, they are helpless, even those who voted for the left were disappointed. Romania is boiling, there are angry people on the streets, and that anger is understandable. And the solution is not a justice system that avenges these attacks and prosecutes even more politicians, but a fair system that respects the rule of law and serves the interests of society, not certain groups. A system like never before in Romania.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, what is happening in this plenary today is a serious misinformation. I will tell you that you are misinformed. I am convinced that you have not read the amendments that have been made to the Criminal Code and the Code of Criminal Procedure, nor to the law that was sent to Parliament, the law of pardon. Because if you had read these documents and this legislation, you would have understood very clearly that there are some requests coming from the Romanian Constitutional Court, as well as some requests coming from the ECHR president regarding the situation in Romanian prisons. So I will ask you, before we have a plenary debate and hurry to point the finger at Romania, to do an analysis in the LIBE Commission and I also invite you in Romania to discuss with the state authorities, with all institutions and to understand the real situation in Romania. It is a pity that we end up in the European Parliament to misinform so badly about the situation in Romania. The situation in Romania is serious, but it refers to rights, freedoms, democracy and respect for justice and the rights of the citizen when he is in court. So I'm waiting for you in Romania.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, beyond any statements made here today, there is a reality that cannot be ignored: more than 400,000 people were on the streets last night in more than 50 cities across the country, and they need aanswer, and this answer is one, namely the abrogation of the emergency ordinance amending, in the evening, the Criminal Code and Criminal Procedure and, if desired, their discussion in the Romanian Parliament, where appropriate.Otherwise, it will endanger both the European course of Romania, but, certainly, the daily life of Romanians, which of course we do not want.Romania is firmly committed to a European path, and their massive presence demonstrates the need to keep these commitments, beyond any other interests.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I greet Mr Timmermans, First Vice-President, and I would like to draw his attention to the following example: he is a Member of the Romanian Parliament.He is re-elected and he hires the staff he had in the previous term to continue working with him.I mean assistants, I mean counselors.Well, he needs to know that he is accused and guilty of a conflict of interest because, in the past, he had a business relationship with his employees and this to me, personally, seems ridiculous and I would like to ask himwhat is his opinion on this.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: - Mr President, dear colleagues, as has already been said, in Romania last night, more than 400 thousand people protested against this emergency ordinance adopted by the Romanian government amending the Criminal Code. These changes decriminalize abuse of office. This ordinance will lead to the release of several convicted politicians and the cessation of many ongoing investigations. It is the biggest blow to justice in Romania in the last twenty-seven years since the fall of communism. Mr. Vice President Timmermans, have you asked why the government is doing such a thing? The answer is simple: because this ordinance will benefit corrupt politicians, including the President of the Romanian Parliament, the Social Democrat Liviu Dragnea. What to do now? I call on all international partners, including the European Commission, to put pressure on the Romanian government so that these adopted changes do not enter into force within the deadline of ten days. It is important for Europe to be with the citizens of Romania in the fight against corrupt politicians. This is waiting for the citizens of Romania in Europe.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, dear First Vice-President, I would first like to say that I appreciate you very much and I have always been impressed by your intelligence and diplomacy, but I must say that you have disappointed me. If you correlate what is happening in Romania with the granting of European funds, I can only think that now, when the 10 years have ended with the MCV, there was a special mechanism to discriminate twenty million Romanians. Mr. First Vice-President, you said about sovereignty in your speech, at the same time you ask the government: either we have parliamentary-government sovereignty, the result of elections, or you impose. Then you said let them do their job. Let's let the government do its job, let justice work. I have always advocated the conviction of thieves, but not the violation of human rights, a correction that is now being tried by this ordinance. Thank you and I would like you to answer me on time.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Mr President, indeed, seen from this Chamber, it is difficult to know what exactly is going on. That is why I am delighted that we have accepted that there be a debate in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs which is more documented than that of today and that indeed, a delegation can go to Romania. What I can say is that I have known Romania for a long time since I was one of the first French to visit Romania after the fall of Ceausescu. I tell myself that Romania is still a young democracy, that it has made a lot of progress but that we really need to strengthen democracy and the rule of law. I believe that today we must ensure that this rule of law can effectively have its prerogatives and work in Romania. It is in this direction, it seems to me, that we must push Romania. The rule of law must be respected and democracy must be respected. I believe this is the root of the problem and this is where we need to go.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I was inspired by what Mr Frunzulică said earlier, that we should not be turning this into a party-political confrontation between government and opposition. Sadly, that happened here in this House today, which, in a sense, is normal in a political chamber – that is what you get – but on this issue I am a bit saddened by that. I would say to your PPE colleagues that they should hold onto the passion with which they spoke today when we are discussing nations where one of your parties is in power. Hold on to that and be exactly the same: you would really help all of us. But for me this has nothing to do with party political issues and, frankly, it is preposterous and rather insulting to suggest that I would be an agent to topple a government led by the party I belong to. That is nonsensical. I am looking at a situation as it is. On these issues, the Commission – as we have shown over the last year and certainly since the Juncker Commission came into being – is colour blind. This is not party political. The issue at hand is very straightforward. We have cooperated with Romania in the last 10 years in the cooperation and verification mechanism (CVM). I have cooperated personally with various governments, of differing compositions, and all these governments have cooperated with me personally – with the Commission – in a constructive way, albeit, of course, blaming the opposition or saying to us that we are more critical of them when they are in power than we are of the opposition. In that sense, regardless of the political colour in Romania, the criticism is always the same. So I accept that criticism. Yes, we are critical and sometimes that hurts if you are in government or in parliament. I understand that, but that is simply our role. That is the role of the Commission, that is the role we have been given in the Treaty and that is the role that also emanates from the CVM. The point I was trying to make this morning is this: Romania is in the final stretch of this long, long marathon, leading to a situation where we can all say the development is now irreversible. Romania is not at risk of going back to what the situation was in the past. We are almost there. That is what the last CVM report stipulated very clearly, and in our perception the emergency ordinance and the draft legislation seem to indicate another direction – backwards – and I think this needs to be discussed. We signalled it in the CVM report last week. This needs to be discussed because it would not speed up the process. It would slow down the process or even stop the process of where we want to go, namely to the point where we, the Commission, can also say that the development is irreversible. That is where we want to get to. So that is why I call upon the authorities in Romania carefully to look into what they are doing. I find it very difficult to understand what emergency would warrant an emergency ordinance on this subject. I find it difficult to understand why lowering the standards on fighting corruption is in the interest of the Romanian nation. I find it difficult to understand but, of course, this is not interference in internal affairs. The Parliament of Romania is sovereign in its decisions, and it also has to face the consequences of those decisions. If we in the Commission believe those consequences might not be positive, I think it is our duty – even if it is uncomfortable to some – to signal that. That is what we are doing – nothing more, nothing less. I say to everyone in this House that you will not help the situation by turning this into a party-political confrontation, by making this a theoretical battle about principles. It is about facts and actions. Let us try to find a cooperative way, as we have done in the past, to come out of this situation. Let us pause for a moment to reflect whether this is the right course to take, given also the reactions in the judiciary in Romania and from the Romanian public. I am encouraged by the fact that so many people attach such great importance to the fight against corruption. Hold on to that: it is a great, great asset. I also see that there is overwhelming support in the Romanian population for the involvement of the European Union in this joint progress towards an irreversible situation. This is strongly supported by the Romanian population. Nobody is saying that the EU should stay out of it. Use this as a strength. I will end with a quote from the famous Romanian sculptor, Brâncuși, who said: ‘Theories are patterns without value. What counts is action.’ Let us take action to make sure that this process, towards an irreversible, strong rule of law where corruption is controlled and rooted out, happens soon in Romania and that we do nothing that would indicate a different direction.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing.- The measure adopted by the Romanian government, which eases the penalties for a complex of minor offenses and for particular cases, has raised many perplexities.This is a measure that goes against the trend of Romania's path so far in the fight against corruption.The recent MCV report, in fact, highlights the fact that the authorities of the Romanian state have achieved good and very good results, that there is considerable progress achieved by the Romanian institutions in the fight against corruption and crime in general.The latest government measures are generating discontent and strong criticism among citizens.Europe must do everything possible for Romania to resume the path of reforms and to continue the process of fighting corruption that the state has been carrying out for a long time.Backtracks are not allowed on this ground, neither to Romania nor to other EU countries.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Mariya Gabriel, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) no.539/2001 of the Council which adopts the list of third countries whose citizens must be in possession of a visa when crossing the external borders and the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from this obligation (Georgia) (COM (2016) 0142 - C8-0113 / 2016 - 2016/0075 (COD)) (A8-0260 / 2016).

name: Мария Габриел
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, dear colleagues, we have come a long way before today's final vote on the abolition of visas for Georgian citizens. This is a recognition of the achievements of the Georgian authorities and citizens. Today is a historic day not only for Georgia but also for the European Union. The introduction of a visa-free regime for Georgia marks a new stage in our relations with the country. Thank you to all colleagues for your strong support in the process of working on this key dossier. The road to this day has not been easy. But the effort was worthwhile on behalf of Georgian and European citizens. In September, the competent committee, LIBE, adopted my report by a large majority. That is how I was given a mandate to negotiate on behalf of the European Parliament. In the meantime, the Council / Member States have linked the entry into force of visa liberalization for Georgia to the strengthening of the visa waiver mechanism. This delayed the start of interinstitutional negotiations. It became possible after an agreement on the suspension mechanism was reached in December last year. The strength of the European Parliament is that we are consistent in our actions. We have always stood for one position: if all the criteria are met, the visa regime will be liberalized. I am glad that the Council has repeatedly supported our commitment to achieve rapid results in the process of visa liberalization for Georgia. The simultaneous entry into force of the suspension mechanism and visa liberalization for Georgia marks the ultimate success of these efforts. The abolition of the visa requirement for Georgia is a strong signal to the citizens. Here I especially want to thank them for the consistency, patience and strength of their democratic convictions. Georgia has not only met all the requirements set by the European Union, but also upgraded them. In this way, the common visa policy of the European Union is proving to be an effective tool for foreign policy in the dialogue with our partners. Georgia has made significant progress in carrying out comprehensive and comprehensive reforms. This brought the country even closer to European values ​​and democratic standards. Georgia is a strategically important partner of the European Union in the framework of the European Neighborhood Policy and in particular of the Eastern Partnership. Moreover, the country also plays a key role in the European Union's efforts to strengthen pan-European security. Europe must be surrounded by friends and partners. That is why it is important that we fulfill our own commitment to the country to abolish visa requirements. In this way, we will guarantee the deepening of our relations in a spirit of mutual trust and dialogue. The introduction of a visa-free regime is essential for both Georgian and European citizens. We must not forget that the real rapprochement of Georgians with our common European values ​​is possible only if they are guaranteed the freedom to travel without a visa. Only in this way can we share our cultures, promote economic and political cohesion, and strengthen the Union's position as an important factor in the region. Last but not least, I would like to call on the Council now to start negotiations without further delay on visa liberalization for Ukraine. Let's meet the expectations of our partners. They also met the criteria. In conclusion, I would like to call on us to strongly support visa liberalization for Georgia today during the vote. In this way, we will fulfill our own principle of visa reciprocity. I believe that today the European Parliament will send a strong positive message to the Georgian citizens. I count on your support.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by expressing our thanks to Ms Gabriel for the excellent job she has done. She was behind all these efforts in order to arrive where we are today. Georgia has been exemplary in fulfilling a demanding roadmap which allowed us to propose to you – and the Council of course – visa liberalisation for its citizens. I am therefore very pleased that Georgian citizens with biometric passports will soon be able to travel to the Schengen area without a visa for a short period of up to 90 days. It is a very important achievement indeed, and it has been a long process.  The EU-Georgia visa liberalisation dialogue, as you will remember, started in June 2012. The continuous monitoring and reporting carried out since then showed that Georgia has made the necessary progress. Georgia has undertaken all the necessary efforts to meet all of the benchmarks. Therefore, following the positive assessment of the progress report, the Commission proposed in March 2016 to lift the visa requirement for Georgian citizens holding a biometric passport. This will be done by amending the Visa Regulation. This proposal also took into account overall EU-Georgia relations.  The hard work, really hard work, of the Georgian authorities over the past two years has paid off. The Commission will continue to monitor Georgia’s continuous compliance with the visa liberalisation criteria, in particular on fighting organised crime. Because, as I have said on other occasions, these reforms bring Georgia closer to European Union standards, facilitating cooperation with the European Union and bringing the country a step forward on its European path.  I would like to remind you that visa-free travel for Georgia will enter into force at the same time as the revised suspension mechanism, even though they are two separate issues. In addition, the suspension mechanism applies to all visa-free countries horizontally, not just to Georgia. It will be an important tool to further enhance security for the European Union, but also a catalyst that will enable our visa liberalisation policy to expand.  Visa liberalisation with Georgia is an essential contribution to strengthen cultural and economic ties between Georgian and EU citizens because, let’s not forget, visa-free travel is a tangible tool of European integration that directly concerns the citizens. I would like to share personal experience with you. When I first visited Tbilisi as European Commissioner, I was very impressed by the many European Union flags around the city – I would say more European flags in Georgia than in Brussels. I was touched, because in a period where we here in the European Union, in the Member States, take our Union for granted and where we see anti-European rhetoric develop, the citizens of Georgia remind us what a unique achievement of peace, stability and prosperity the European Union is.  Dear Members of the European Parliament, let me conclude by calling on you to support the proposal on the table later during the vote.

name: Andrejs Mamikins
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. –   Mr President, dear colleagues, dear Georgian friends, I would like to say some words about the process of adoption of the visa-free regime with Georgia. It was very ugly. The Council’s idea to connect the visa-free regime between the EU and Georgia and Ukraine with the visa suspension mechanism was, in my opinion, a bad idea. As a result, an unexpected delay occurred and nobody could say when this process would be finished. Some EU country leaders publicly declared that they were glad to see these Eastern European countries on the way of European integration, but at the same time behind closed doors they put their feet on the brakes and started to blackmail the European Parliament. In this way they tried to solve their internal political problems. Colleagues, in politics as in a business company, reputation of reliable partners is a very valuable thing, and the reputation of the EU in this case, in my opinion, was seriously damaged. I would like to apologise to our Georgian friends for this unpleasant experience. Nevertheless, dear colleagues, now in this Chamber among us is the Speaker of the Parliament of Georgia, the best friend of the European Parliament and Europe, his Excellency Irakli Kobakhidze. Dear Georgian friends, I hope that today’s decision will give impetus for the new achievements in cooperation between Georgia and the European Union. Fulfilling all the criteria for adopting the free visa regime was not an easy task but the Georgians have done a great job. It is a very important step on the path of the European integration of Georgia. It is a great achievement of the Georgian people, politicians, civil society, students and so on.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner. I congratulate the rapporteur Maríya Gabriel for her professional and committed work, as well as the Georgian people and authorities. As I have repeatedly stated, Georgia has long deserved visa exemption, as it fulfilled all the requirements set out in Article -1 of Regulation No 539/2001. I never understood the unnecessary link of this file with others in negotiation. Since May last year we have been working intensively to improve the suspension mechanism, for whose report - as you know - I am the rapporteur. I sincerely hope that the definitive approval of the mechanism, the correction that we will carry out during the next plenary session, will serve to ensure the definitive entry into force of the visa waiver agreement that we are debating today. No one would understand any delay that would prevent its signing on March 1, its publication beyond March 9 and its entry into force before the end of the same month. For this reason, I ask the current Presidency for the greatest possible diligence to carry out all the pertinent procedures with the Council that entail the final approval of both files, their signature and their publication. This Agreement will deepen and improve the reciprocal relations between Georgia and the European Union. And as has already been demonstrated in many other cases, it will have beneficial effects for both parties in areas as disparate as security, tourism, culture or defense and, above all, it will serve to bring Georgia much closer to Europe.

name: Birgit Sippel
text: on behalf of the S&D Group.-  Mister President!As early as December 2015, the European Commission confirmed that Georgia had met all the criteria of the action plan for visa liberalization.Voilà!The fact that the people in Georgia are still waiting for this visa liberalization was also due to the member states, which then additionally linked this visa facilitation to a so-called suspension mechanism.Thanks to the persistence and willingness to compromise on the part of the European Parliament and, in particular, of our rapporteur, we have now been able to adopt this mechanism - on clear terms and against the will of the Council, including a mechanism of democratic control by this House.Georgia has waited long enough for the hard-won visa facilitation.It is time to finally put this freedom of travel into effect.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. –  Mr President, it was a long way for Georgians, regardless of their political option. It was a long way for many of us participating in the first Congress of Polish Solidarność, extending a friendly message to all nations suffering under Communist rule. I welcome this report, and I await quick decisions concerning Ukraine.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am obviously delighted, like my colleagues, at the finalization of this liberalization agreement and I would like to salute the excellent work we have done with Mariya Gabriel, our very efficient rapporteur . Georgia has demonstrated, in recent years, a very clear desire for rapprochement with the Union, a political will but above all a concrete will, which has resulted in a certain number of responses to all the criteria that had been demanded and imposed. , as was recalled a moment ago, and that it has made all the necessary progress in order to benefit from this liberalization regime. While I welcome these advances, it must, however, be stressed that these many reforms implemented by Georgia must not, of course, be the result of one day. They must be maintained, consolidated and sustainable in all the key areas of media independence and pluralism, judicial independence, respect for minority rights and the fight against organized crime. This agreement marks an important step in the deepening of relations, but also because Georgia is an actor, a key partner, a strategic partner in the framework of the European Neighborhood Policy and more particularly of the Eastern Partnership. I am thinking in particular - and I stress - of cooperation in the field of home affairs and the fight against organized crime. In this context, in our extremely unstable geopolitical context and for some citizens, distressing, there is no need for long comments to understand how strategic it is to establish privileged relations with these countries of the South Caucasus, to make it partners and friends, friends also among citizens.

name: Bodil Valero
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President! I would also like to welcome the proposal. This could have gone much faster. We could have granted visa facilitation much earlier. Nor can I really understand what Mr Díaz de Mera mentioned here earlier: that we should wait, that we must link this to the so-called repeal mechanism. They do not have direct contact with each other. They have connections in a certain way, but they are not something that you absolutely have to take together. It is a fact that Georgia has long met all the criteria for obtaining these visa facilitation. What I also very much welcome is that it is now a matter of allowing Georgian citizens to come to us as well, and not just us who are to come to them without a visa, as it is today. So I also want to congratulate the Georgian citizens here today, because I think it's time we actually took this step now. When it comes to visa facilitation in general, our attitude is that it is very important that free movement not only includes us in Europe, but that we extend it to other countries as well. The easier it is for people to move across borders, the better, we also believe. Actually, there should be no borders in the world, but it is a utopia, so we can not expect it to go in that direction. But I really want to welcome this proposal today, and hope that it can enter into force as early as possible and not really at all linked to this repeal mechanism. Thanks!

name: Gerard Batten
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. –  Mr President, well, the Treaty of Rome is burning. And while it’s burning you’re fiddling, specifically fiddling with visa restriction rules. A lot of people were very upset in this Chamber yesterday and there were some very disgraceful scenes, and it was the people who would like Britain to remain in the EU getting upset with the people on this side who want it to leave. Now the truth is finally dawning on you here that Britain is going to leave and the European Union is going to lose one of its biggest net contributors.  Perhaps it would be good for you to understand that the central issue on why we decided to leave was because of a loss of democracy and national sovereignty and control, and the biggest issue that brought that home to the British people was the issue of immigration, and specifically mass uncontrolled immigration, which is what we’ve had for many years, specifically from the European Union in great numbers since 1997. To give you an idea on those figures, last year the official figure is that we had 650 000 people come into the country, but there were 825 000 National Insurance numbers issued, so it’s out of control and nobody knows what the real figures are. To come onto the specifics of what we’re discussing here, this is a technical change, I understand, which would give Georgia visa-free access to the European Union for a period of 90 days, and as the rapporteur Ms Gabriel says, the EU remains a very attractive destination. Well, it’s true that back in the 18th century Dr Johnson said the most attractive thing about Scotland was the road to England. That’s still true, and in the 21st  century equivalent the most attractive thing for many countries on the periphery of Europe is the road somewhere else, and one can hardly blame them.  Now perhaps there is something that you should consider. The British people voted to leave the European Union for many reasons, and one of the biggest ones was mass immigration. You’re actually making the problem worse for the European Union because you are extending these visa arrangements to people, who can come, there are then very few or no checks, they can overstay their welcome, and once inside the Schengen area, they can move anywhere else that they like.  You are going to lose Britain, and I wish you well when we’ve left. I don’t want to destroy the European Union; if that’s what you want, then good luck to you. But you’re going to destroy your own project because the next countries that are going want to leave are Germany, Holland, France and more. So in your own interest. I think you should wake up to what’s happening in the real world.   (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8).)

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: blue card issue.- Dear colleagues!Thank you for accepting my blue card question!I am really pleased that you will not be sitting in this Chamber any time soon, as much as you want to leave this post and fight for your country to leave the European Union.But tell me, what migration threats did you just talk about?Do you know how many people live in Georgia?Do you really see that around three and a half million people are a threat to the European Union if they go to have a beer in Riga or live in a hotel in Berlin?Thanks!

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Well, there were two parts to your question. The first one was about Brexit, and I can tell you that we want to leave as quickly as possible. I am the UKIP Brexit spokesman, and I’m writing a plan which would get Britain out of the European Union a very much a great deal faster than Theresa May’s, and soon as it’s done I’ll be happy to send you a copy. The day that I leave here and Britain is restored as an independent country, I will be very, very happy, and pleased to make you happy as well.  The second part of your question was about 3.7 million people in Georgia, I believe, and it’s not about the actual numbers in Georgia – we’ve had this from every country in the European Union. We were told that about 13 000 people would come from Poland. I think that the figure is at least 700 000 – it’s over a million, probably, and we in Britain have no problem with people going to other countries. It’s a matter of numbers and the degree. That is the problem.

name: Vicky Maeijer
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - And again a dubious country from Brussels gets visa liberalization as a gift, this time Georgia. While Europe is plagued by organized crime from the former Soviet country, millions of Georgians will soon be allowed to travel freely through Europe. Previously, it was the asylum procedures that were massively abused by Georgian criminals to come and rob, steal, extort and assault in European cities. That will no longer be necessary, because visa exemption makes it super easy for criminals to go on a raid. Figures from 2016 showed that more than 8,000 Georgian criminals were registered in Germany alone in one year, and Brussels doesn't care at all. The Netherlands has to decide for itself who will and who will not enter our country. The free movement of persons has meanwhile become the free movement of asylum seekers, terrorists and weapons. My party is for safety. The PVV is against more European Union and that is why my group is against the visa-free regime for Georgia. (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)).)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, you come from a European country. Your country has important European values, and you are Europeans because of your traditions, culture, history and values. So is Georgia. They fulfilled all the benchmarks required in order to receive this, and they are also a European country, and we have to send them the message that they could become one day Members of the European Union. That’s why we have to implement, as soon as possible, this visa liberalisation for Georgian citizens. Don’t you agree that you and all the other MEPs, who come from European countries, have to support this – not to be against?

name: Vicky Maeijer (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer.- Obviously I don't support that.Because freedom and security are the values that I defend, that my party defends.In order to defend them, what we need is absolutely not more European Union, but less European Union.

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Mr President, when Ms Merkel made the monumental error of judgment by opening the doors of Germany to those from all countries without positive checks, we now have seen the consequences. The European Union, in its desire to continue to extend its influence – or, as some would say, its empire – is doing two things. The first of those is making the same mistakes by not making sure it checks those who are coming in. In the Library of Congress on Georgia, it says that borders with Turkey are porous and dangerous for terrorists. In June of last year, the Georgian newspaper Rezonansi reported that ISIS had established a special—purpose vehicle brigade of 600—700 terrorists to use Georgia as a transit corridor for ISIS. Please do not make the same mistakes, with your huge desire to have open borders between all countries of Europe, that Merkel made last year.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to give special thanks to Mariya Gabriel, the rapporteur. I would like to take this one minute and turn to Georgia’s citizens. Dear Georgians, today’s decision of the European Parliament is one of the last miles in your visa liberalisation marathon. You deserve it, and I am proud to be part of the decision by voting in favour. Liberalisation of the visa regime provides you with a lot of opportunities and advantages. Use it to the benefit of the development of your country. To meet the visa liberalisation benchmarks was a challenge to which you have risen. There will be more reform challenges from the Association Agenda to meet. I am convinced that the decision on visa liberalisation will yield even more energy and enthusiasm to deliver on those new challenges.  Dear Georgians, your country is not suspicious. You are a very proud, brave European nation. I am keeping my fingers crossed.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: - The visa-free regime between Georgia and the European Union is desirable and due, since Georgia has taken all the necessary measures for more than a year to meet the European Union's demanding standards. And your people and institutions are committed to consolidating democracy and imbued with a pro-European spirit, as I was able to see, as head of the European Parliament's observation mission to the elections in Georgia a few months ago. It becomes even more important that this regime enters into force without delay, in view of the tectonic changes taking place in the international political context, with Trump, President of the United States, serving Putin's strategy, aimed at destroying the European Union and democracy. We therefore need to reorganize forces and support all those who, in Georgia, are opposed to the Russian occupation of their territory and are working to intensify economic and political relations with the European Union. Visa waivers will facilitate exchanges of people at all levels and give democratic forces in Georgia a clear signal that we want to help them consolidate their democracy and their autonomy. My greetings to the President of the Georgian Parliament and his delegation, who are here with us today, and to colleague Maria Gabriel for her commitment as rapporteur in this process.

name: Sajjad Karim (ECR).
text: – Mr President, it amazes me how our Parliament can be the best of parliaments and the worst of parliaments in the same session, all at the same time. Whilst I rise and it gives me a huge amount of personal pleasure to be able to congratulate Georgia on such a tremendous achievement, let me also make it clear that the vast majority of this House stands absolutely united in rejecting the alternative facts and the bare racism that is demonstrated by a very small minority of people in this House, who speak about things that they do not understand. I apologise to colleagues for my anger that is coming through today, but may I echo the words of our Commissioner when he stands and says that Georgia made him proud. Let our Commissioner know that this House stands united behind him because we have all seen those same flags in Georgia. We have seen their commitment. We have seen how their sovereignty and territorial integrity remains compromised but yet they stand firm, through their people, on their European way. Let Europe stand firm with them. We owe it at least to them to stand united in the face of these alternative facts and this changing geopolitical situation that is emerging in the world today.  (Applause)

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: - The question of whether to abolish visas for Georgian citizens is, first and foremost, a question of whether the European Union wants to have an effective external relations policy.Georgia has long been striving for rapprochement with the European Union, which has led to many difficult reforms, and they have suffered greatly from their less friendly neighbor.And it all happened in the knowledge that in exchange for Georgia's Europeanization, awards such as a visa-free regime are being offered.Therefore, by abolishing visas for Georgian citizens, we will show that the European Union is living up to its responsibilities and will encourage our other neighbors to develop good governance and democracy, protect human rights and adhere to the principles of a market economy.We all know that the reforms have been successful.Georgia is a democratic, stable country that respects human rights and European values.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). - Mr President, we should not even seriously discuss the prospect of visa liberalization for Georgian nationals. This country is facing huge problems of corruption and fake passports have been identified many times. In addition, it is dealing with widespread and well-organized crime, which it has already exported to several countries in the Union. Also, the country's political staff is reminiscent of other times and situations, with former presidents even becoming prefects in neighboring countries, perhaps they avoid prison with the support of the European Union of course. As far as human rights are concerned, the people of Abkhazia and South Ossetia, whom you refer to in the report as populations, as if you were talking about sheep, have experienced and continue to experience Georgia's "progress" in this area on a daily basis. It carried out its armed forces against civilians and was eventually forced to withdraw when Russian tanks reached a few kilometers outside Tbilisi. All this is happening with the support of the Union, which defends the right of peoples to self-determination very selectively.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to openly declare my support for granting a visa-free regime to the Georgian people. I have met many Georgians, especially young Georgians, and I am happy to observe their enthusiasm and dedication to the idea of bringing their country closer to the EU. They feel that European roots are an essential part of their identity and I believe that the Georgian nation does indeed deserve to have a European future one day.  However, in these difficult times, we need to pragmatic and look well at the reasons why we should support Georgia. One such reason is the increasingly tense security situation in the Black Sea region. Georgia is strategically important, not just as a transit country but also as the only pro-western littoral state along the eastern shores of the Black Sea.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I very much welcome the visa—free regime for Georgia. We are today in a highly volatile political context, we need our strategic partners more than ever, and we need to prove to them that they can rely on us. Georgia has shown its strong commitments towards European values and integration, and it undertook reforms that were not easy. Despite the visa-free delays, Georgia’s citizens demonstrated once again in the recent parliamentary elections what they stand for, and it is high time to give them tangible signals – in fact, nothing more than what we promised, and what they have been waiting for for too long. According to the European Commission report, Georgia was already meeting the visa liberalisation Action Plan requirements in December 2015 and it is a pity that our Georgian partners had to wait until now to reach this important objective. Finally, considering that all necessary elements are in place, I hope also that the visa liberalisation process for Ukraine will be completed with no further delay.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, that the EU countries recently exercised caution in their visa liberalisation policy after an uncontrolled influx of more than a million refugees and migrants can be easily understandable. However, considering the hard geo-political choices Georgia has made about the country’s future and the far-reaching and difficult reforms it has implemented in the Justice and Home Affairs area, it is time for the EU to show that once its benchmarks are fulfilled, it can also deliver on its promises. I agree with the rapporteur that the visa waiver for Georgian citizens should prove an important tool for enhancing economic and cultural relations, and provide a stable framework for a dialogue on fundamental rights. Ultimately, in difficult political weather, it could also be one small step for Europe in securing democratic development in its turbulent neighbourhood.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, visa waiver for Georgian citizens traveling to the European Union is an important tool for strengthening economic and cultural relations with this important country, but also for intensifying political dialogue on human rights and fundamental freedoms. Georgia is a strategic partner of Europe in the framework of the neighborhood policy and, in particular, of the Eastern Partnership. The Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia signed in 2014 helped to take relations to a new level and strengthened cooperation in many areas. The contribution of the country of the former Soviet Union in the fight against organized crime, including terrorism, corruption and human trafficking, could be useful. Over the past two years, Georgia has made the necessary progress and met all the benchmarks set in the Visa Liberalization Action Plan. Therefore, I welcome the decision to exempt Georgian citizens traveling in the European Union from visa.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, at a time when Greece and the European Union are facing huge refugee and migration flows, the European Union decides to exempt Georgian citizens traveling to the European Union for a short period of time from the visa requirement. Of course, the decision to abolish the visa takes Georgia one step closer to its European course. But for that to happen, it must be ensured that Georgia respects human rights, the rule of law and the rights of minorities. We should not forget that in Georgia there is a Greek minority that has lived and worked in this country for hundreds of years. We therefore call on the competent Georgian authorities to fully respect the rights of the Greek minority and, in addition, to ensure that their homes are handed over to the Greek Pontians, which, unfortunately, have been illegally occupied by third parties.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I think that today we have an excellent reason to congratulate both the European Union and Georgia. Let’s be frank: Georgia has made a great step forward towards Europeanisation. We have to admit that Georgia’s progress in many areas, such as the fight against corruption, the judiciary, better border control, and producing better passports for its own citizens, is self—evident. But of course Georgia has not completed everything and I wish Georgia all the best on its way.  But, colleagues, let us again be frank. We have even better reason to congratulate the European Union, since today the European Union is building a partnership and not a wall, as unfortunately some countries are doing in today’s world.
