I am very hopeful that Ukraine will follow suit and that we will in a short time approve the decision on visa liberalisation for Ukraine.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Georgia has successfully fulfilled the conditions set for it, demonstrating its commitment to closer relations with the Union. For its part, it did everything in its power to abolish the visa requirement. The suspension mechanism was born to prevent abuse, so it is now up to the Union to keep its promises. The credibility of the Union is at stake, if the visa waiver is further delayed, it would send a bad geopolitical message to the region. From the very beginning, it has been a priority for us, including Hungary, for the European Union to add Georgia to the list of visa-free countries. It is also my personal belief that Georgian citizens with biometric passports should have been traveling without a visa for some time. In the same way as Ukrainian citizens. After all, Ukraine, like Georgia, deserved a visa-free regime. It has met all EU conditions, a double standard is not justified.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I support the abolition of short-stay visas for Georgia.This country is our important partner and is also seeking membership in NATO.Georgia has met all the conditions, and as the Commissioner said here, the European Commission will continue to monitor the conditions for visa-free travel.We have adopted a mechanism for suspending visa-free travel, so there may be no concern that we may not be able to stop visa-free travel in the event of a large increase in migrants or a large increase in asylum applications.Georgia has gone through a very difficult period, and I think we can congratulate the Georgians on achieving their goals, which is an important signal to them that it is worth fighting for and continuing with reforms.I would like us to make the same progress and the same success in visa liberalization with Ukraine.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of Parliament, let me start by expressing my thanks for this debate. I am really glad at the end of this session that there is a large consensus in this House on the need to keep the promises the European Union has made to the people of Georgia. The Georgian Government has indeed worked very hard to fulfil all the benchmarks of the Visa Liberalisation Action Plan, and I would like to commend and praise once again the government for its commitment.  Should there be any problems after visa liberalisation, the revised suspension mechanism is there to deal with that. We will continue to monitor the situation. There is no need to delay this important file any further. Let us proceed with the voting on the report by Ms Gabriel, which will bring us one step closer to the conclusion of the whole procedure to grant visa-free travel for the citizens of this great country.

name: Мария Габриел
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner, I would first like to thank my colleagues for their support and for the clear messages. Thank you, Commissioner, for the constant dialogue and good cooperation on the difficult work on this dossier. I just want to say two things. Approval today for visa-free travel for Georgian citizens is not a gesture. It is a recognition, it is also a challenge. Recognition for the work done by the Georgian authorities, recognition for the defense of our common European democratic values ​​and by the Georgian citizens. Today's vote is also a challenge. A challenge to continue to deepen our partnership with Georgia, a challenge to our cultural, economic and political ties. I therefore call on the Council to finalize the procedure as soon as possible so that we can fulfill our commitment before the end of March. Once again, when we talk about visas, let us always remember that we are talking about citizens. We owe it to them in the name of our common shared values, in the name of our common security, in the name of our common future. We must now move on to the last stage of the procedure.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I have a feeling that I took part in the historical debate.I am glad that I led it.I greet our Georgian friends in the galleries for the public.I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 2 February 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written.- Georgia is an important trade partner of the EU, and a key player in terms of security challenges in the Eastern Partnership.Precisely because of this, it is necessary to strengthen the principle according to which any country that has successfully met all the criteria can benefit from visa liberalization, but the criteria that led to liberalization must be systematically respected.Georgia has made obvious progress in implementing the Visa Liberalization Action Plan (VLAP), and has succeeded in meeting the necessary benchmarks.Such a thing brings significant advantages for Georgian citizens as well.Although Georgia is a country of stable democracy, which has launched concrete measures to fight organized crime, including trafficking in human beings, terrorism and corruption, efforts need to be further stepped up to make progress in media freedom, judicial independence and fair elections.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- Georgia has been ready for visa-free travel with the EU for some time, and it is good that the European Parliament has approved it.Visa liberalization contributes to people-to-people contacts and also to the promotion of economic relations.Hopefully, we will also be able to move forward with visa-free travel for Ukraine soon.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - An important element of the European Union's neighborhood policy is the Eastern Partnership, which plays a central role in our efforts to stabilize and democratize the EU's eastern borders. Given that this is in the interests of both the partners concerned and the EU Member States, Georgia can be seen as one of the success stories of our neighborhood policy, based on the implementation of the Association Agreement with Georgia and the nearly five years of intensive work to implement the Visa Liberalization Action Plan. The possibility of visa-free travel, which the Georgian side has already unilaterally granted to EU citizens, could open up new areas of public relations and business opportunities. Of course, it cannot be overlooked that the European Union is the most popular destination for those wishing to emigrate from Georgia, but based on previous parliamentary debates and the proposal, I believe that the monitoring and suspension mechanism provided for in the agreement provides sufficient safeguards against possible abuses. I note that the EU's favorable assessment also applies to the assessment of Ukraine's EU visa liberalization, which is being discussed in practice in parallel with the Georgian case, and the successful implementation of which will be an important stage for both our partners in European values ​​and democratic structures.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: in writing.- I support the joint proposal of the European Parliament and the Council to exempt Georgian citizens from the visa requirement within the European Union if they have biometric passports.Let us remember that Georgia took the first step by lifting the visa requirement for citizens of all EU countries, if their stay in Georgia does not exceed 90 days.The adoption of similar measures in relation to Georgian citizens will be an important instrument to strengthen cultural and economic contacts with the country.Georgia is a key partner of the EU under the Common Neighborhood Policy.We should be interested in a gradual rapprochement between the EU and Georgia.This solution will be important especially for students, scientists, teachers and entrepreneurs.At the same time, however, the EU should monitor the situation in Georgia, stressing the importance of the rule of law and the independence of the judiciary in that country.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the report by Tadeusz Zwiefka, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, with recommendations to the Commission on cross-border aspects of adoptions (2015/2086 (INL)) (A8-0370 / 2016).

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka
text: rapporteur. - Commissioner! Colleagues! When we started working on this report in the Committee on Legal Affairs, we were asking ourselves one fundamental question: what is the real purpose of the adoption procedure? The answer was simple and clear to everyone: this goal is to create a good, friendly, loving environment for the proper development of the child. The child's welfare is the primary goal for which adoption procedures are carried out. The agreement to this statement was a very good starting point for a discussion on the content of the report, which I finally divided into two parts. In the first part, we discuss various aspects of adoption procedures. It seems that despite their improvement every year, there are still serious shortcomings, there are still question marks that need to be answered. Therefore, I am calling for the creation of even minimum standards that would allow all Member States of the European Union to act according to the same rules. What are these minimum standards? First of all, respecting the child's subjectivity. A child is an individual person, it is no one's property. Thus, in the adoption procedure, where this is already possible, the child should be heard before making a decision. It is also hard to imagine that adoption decisions would be made without listening to the biological parents, if they are alive, without their consent, or without exhausting the procedural line for depriving biological parents of parental authority. There are still many such issues. We also talked about how the 1993 Hague Convention on International Adoption works. This is an important instrument, a very important document, but it only regulates those adoptions that are carried out on a cross-border basis. However, it does not say how we should help each other in the event of domestic adoption. I also mention in my report the issue of training judges and staff at adoption centers who deal with this subject matter, so that the procedures are similar, so that we approach the issue of the best interests of the child in a similar way. I want to make it very clear that there is not a single word in the entire report about changing substantive family law. We know very well that this is an exclusive competence of the Member States and it should remain so. However, where possible, we should jointly develop procedures that will ensure the best interests of the child in an even more appropriate way. Hence, in the second part of my report, I present a legislative proposal: I am asking the European Commission to prepare a proposal for a Council regulation on the recognition of domestic adoptions. National adoptions, carried out according to national law, take place in situations where both the adoptive parents and the adopted child reside, live in the same country, are nationals of the same country. When they move to another country, these procedures have to be repeated. This is obviously a financial and time problem and creates legal uncertainty. Therefore, the introduction of automatic mutual recognition of domestic adoption orders would change and improve this situation. I am also requesting the preparation of a multilingual adoption certificate, similar to the inheritance certificate, which we adopted two years ago and which is working perfectly.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the protection and promotion of children’s rights is a real priority for the Commission. We must ensure that the rights of those who are in particularly difficult situations, such as the victims of abduction or children in migration, are fully respected and promoted. For instance the proposal for the recast of the Brussels IIA Regulation, which was adopted last year on 30 June, strengthens the rights of the child. It introduces a new obligation concerning the hearing of children and specific measures to enhance the efficiency of return proceedings in cases of parental abduction.  I would like to thank Mr Zwiefka for his comprehensive report. I fully support the call on Member States to strengthen mutual trust and administrative cooperation between them on this important matter. Training for legal practitioners working in the field of cross-border adoption is essential in this respect. The Commission is ready to co-finance relevant projects proposed by interested Member States and stakeholders in line with the current financial framework. The Commission is aware that the lack of recognition of adoption orders between Member States may entail problems both for the parents and, especially, for the child, but we lack updated data on this. The Commission did a study on the subject back in 2009 which was discussed at a joint conference with the Council of Europe in the very same year. However, that study did not provide the Commission with data, as Member States either did not keep statistics or simply did not want to share them. We are aware that adoptive parents may encounter problems when they move to another Member State and that the adopted children’s civil status may be questioned.  But let me be clear: this is a very sensitive area of law and, for any legislative proposal in the area of family law to be adopted, we need unanimity in the Council. You mentioned yourself that family law is a domain for the Member States. Any initiative on the recognition of adoption orders at EU level therefore needs to be very strongly evidence-based. For instance, how many cases of lack of recognition are we talking about? What are the key aspects invoked when recognition is challenged? How are Member States dealing with such cases?  Currently, preliminary work and consultation regarding a possible initiative on the recognition of domestic adoptions are being carried out at international level in the context of the Hague Conference on Private International Law. Further developments within the Hague Conference can help clarify the depth and extent of the problem and the willingness of Member States to deal with it at international level, as well as any need for corresponding action at EU level. I am following this issue closely and will keep Parliament informed. In parallel, we will continue to support Member States on this.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: Author of the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. - Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for the views he has expressed. The issue of cross-border aspects of adoption has been on the agenda of the Committee on Petitions many times, where we have discussed this issue and consider it very important. Recently, significant issues have arisen in relation to cross-border adoptions that require a different approach by the European Commission. First of all, we must ensure that all adoption decisions are made solely in the best interests of the child for a better tomorrow. That is why it is important, depending on the age and maturity of the child, to always take into account the opinion of the child himself. At the same time, every effort must be made to ensure that the siblings are not separated and that the identity of the child is maintained. In addition, it is necessary to take European legislative action to facilitate cross-border recognition of adoption decisions and to stop excessive bureaucratic formalities between Member States. Finally, austerity and cut-off policies are certainly having a negative impact on social services themselves, which also play an important role in this regard.

name: Pavel Svoboda
text: for the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, the problem of cross-border recognition of adoption is one of the problems whose solution contributes to simplifying the lives of EU citizens. The mobility of European citizens is a fact that needs to be taken into account today, and rules need to be created that will make it easier, not more difficult, to exercise freedom of movement within the EU. If we are in favor of recognizing individual adoption decisions throughout the Union today, we are not creating Europe from above, but we are responding to an existing reality, to the ever-increasing personal ties between Europeans, to the emerging European demos. A mechanism that will allow cross-border recognition of adoption decisions without interfering with national rules governing adoption is the measure that its citizens expect from the EU. I would therefore like to thank my colleagues from the JURI, but above all the rapporteur, Tadeusz Zwiefek, for making this report so excellent.

name: Virginie Rozière
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur and all colleagues for the excellent work that has been done on this issue. Commissioner, you said that all action must be based on facts, but our Parliament is regularly seized of situations of families who face very serious difficulties when moving around the European Union. They face enormous difficulties in having family ties recognized and in living a normal family life. In this area, as in others, I am convinced that the European Union can be the solution. In this sense, the report proposes important steps forward to deal with the collapsing legal landscape in the various Member States of the European Union. I think that beyond the reluctance that can be attached to such and such aspects, it is the best interests of the child and, quite simply, the right to live a normal family life, which must guide our action. . I believe that the proposal for a regulation which is annexed to this report is the best instrument to guarantee real legal certainty and effectively safeguard the fundamental rights of these families, who find themselves confronted with these difficulties. This regulation would allow children in fragile situations to be effectively protected against harmful risks of trafficking or adoption, while allowing a peaceful family life in such cases. Finally, I welcome the fact that a solid reference is made to Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights to combat any form of discrimination in adoption recognition procedures. It is an essential objective that we must defend. Given that this text presents real progress for citizens, I think that we will give it in this Parliament a vote and full support and I hope, Madam Commissioner, that you will take them into account in your future work.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about a proposal to adopt a regulation that allows for the automatic recognition of adoption judgments given in another Member State. A necessary condition for the adoption of rules allowing the automatic recognition of such decisions issued in another Member State is to ensure full compliance with national public policy provisions and the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. I support the strengthening of judicial cooperation in the field of grounds, as it is our duty to provide the best possible for the most vulnerable in society. I agree with the rapporteur, Mr Zvefka, that Council Regulation (EC) № 2201/2003 on competence and parental responsibility did not address the issue of recognition of adoptions and that the proposed legislation could complement the existing regulation, filling the gap in recognition of the adoptee in accordance with international law. I refer in particular to the 1993 Hague Convention. In accordance with Article 81 (3) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, I agree that the Council, using its right of derogation, may establish certain measures relating to family law which have cross-border significance. The only legitimate aim is to formulate a common family law for European citizens living in different countries of the Union or who have moved to another country, so that they do not face unnecessary and unjustified obstacles. However, the new regulation requires prior adoption by each of the states, even those that have nothing to do with the case. However, there is another aspect that is important to keep in mind, as it concerns sovereignty in the field of family law of states. Pursuant to Article 6 of the draft regulation, recognition and acceptance orders made in a Member State may be refused only where the rules on jurisdiction is not respected or acceptance is contrary to public policy in a Member State.That is why any final EU intervention in the national policy of the states is unjustified on this topic.This is also the case with my proposal, which uses the strongest instrument - the regulation.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, I would like to thank Mrs Jourová and the rapporteur, Mr Zwiefka, who did extremely precise and high quality work. I am not going to make a long speech to emphasize what my colleagues have already said. I therefore fully support this report, the objective of which is to impose on the countries of the European Union the automatic recognition of orders made in one of the countries of the Union, so as to make life easier for adoptive parents who circulate in the European Union. There was, until now, a terrible contradiction: the European Union had succeeded in settling the issue of the free movement of goods, capital, men and women, but not that of adopted children. We are on the right track and I would like to say that what touches me about this report is that it takes into account the best good of the child. Therefore, I fully support and thank the rapporteur and the Commission proposal.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, cross-border adoptions in the European Union are an important issue, affecting the fortunes of thousands of families who have adopted or want to adopt a child. The existing regulations not only do not ensure the protection of children and parents but actually create obstacles to their free movement between Member States of the Union as in many cases repetitive bureaucratic procedures are required which often prevent families from moving to another Member State. Child protection must be a priority for all of us and cross-border recognition of adoption certificates contributes to this goal. Although there are individual issues to be resolved, I believe that, in general, the report by Mr Zwiefka is moving in a very positive direction and we must move forward to improve adoption procedures, to remove the obstacles that afflict thousands of Europeans. citizens and, above all, that children do not pay the price for the lack of cooperation between states.

name: Pascal Durand
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, thank you very much for giving me the floor twice, but I will not use it too long. Simply, I would first like to thank Mr Zwiefka for the work that has been done. The subject is a difficult subject. It sometimes touches the conscience, it touches the rules of the family, it thus touches the depths of what constitutes our lives. Mr. Zwiefka was able to find a piece of land which was of prime interest. He said it, these are the words he used, and I want to take them back because they justify both the report and the work we have all done together, “the emotional environment” and “the well-being of the child ”. Thank you, Mr Zwiefka, for basing your report on these two concepts: they sum up, in fact, the position and the work we have done. This has been said - I will not repeat it - we are here in the presence of a call from the heart, to ensure that children do not suffer, across the Union, from the disparity between certain laws. This is the work that we have done. Automatic recognition, Commissioner, is necessary. And, indeed, Mr. Cavada rightly said, we cannot have free movement of goods, free movement of finance and not have, for children, this same reciprocal recognition within of the Union. I therefore wanted to give my warmest support to Mr Zwiefka and his report, and to thank all of my colleagues for their work, urging the Commissioner to ensure that the best interests of children are taken into account. account within the Union. (The speaker accepts to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: question "blue card".- Mr President, dear colleague, I do believe that the main objective is to promote the rights of the child and that is also the subject of my question.Don't you think the adoption procedures are very long?Also, I believe that it is necessary to intensify the cooperation between the national authorities to lead to the implementation of this important report.

name: Pascal Durand (Verts/ALE)
text: answer "blue card".- There is no difficulty or disagreement between us.Yes, the procedures are too long and we are trying to ensure that a European legal area means that there is what is called exequatur, that is to say, basically, that a Staterecognize an adoption which took place in another State within the Union.It exists for a number of other rights and adoption law has to be part of it, but in a context that is particular - as I said, it sometimes touches the conscience of people.The child must not be the victim of legal disparities within the Union.That’s the whole point of Mr Zwiefka’s report, so I think we’re okay with ending these lengthy proceedings.

name: Jane Collins
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, adoption is a wonderful alternative for otherwise unwanted children, or a child that’s left in an unsafe environment. But what concerns me about this report is that it’s another power grab by Brussels over the jurisdiction of family law. In the UK, there are strict laws about family courts, including the privacy of proceedings for what is and always will be a very emotive subject. But what I fear, with this latest demand for ‘more Europe’, is that the best interests of the child may be put second to the EU’s desire for more and more power. And what happens if it is a disputed adoption? If the grandparents want to adopt? Or one parent is actually fighting the case? How will that work if the child is taken across another country’s border, into another culture, or maybe where the child will be brought up speaking a different language? I believe that we all should be encouraging families to be strong and cohesive units, which is the best environment for bringing up a child, surely. We should not be making it easier for families to be torn apart.  (The speaker refused to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)) In this Parliament, a great deal of disrespect was shown to my colleague, Nigel Farage. Unfortunately, until our colleagues can show each other respect, I’m afraid I won’t take any more blue cards.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, international adoption is a delicate problem which requires finding a balance between, on the one hand, taking into account the interests of children and families, and, on the other hand, respect for sovereignty of states. The Hague Convention of May 29, 1993 succeeded in achieving this delicate balance. Should we therefore risk going further? This is what the Zwiefka report thinks. While recognizing the good intentions of this report, I believe that it puts too much emphasis on the best interests of children and families at the expense of state sovereignty. It extends the obligation of automatic recognition to national adoptions, which seems unwise to me, because if we are not careful, this risks forcing States to recognize the validity of adoptions made by same-sex couples. or adoptions carried out following surrogacy. However, many European states do not accept the validity of such adoptions. The report further calls for the creation of a European adoption certificate which seems to me to interfere excessively with the competences of the Member States. For these reasons I am against this report. (The speaker agrees to answer a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka (PPE)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Dear Colleague Lebreton!I would just like to ask, how is it possible that, on the one hand, you accept the Hague Convention of 1993 regulating only and exclusively cross-border, international adoptions (against which you later speak a little illogically), and you do not want to agree to respect the decisionadoption issued in the country.After all, the state always strives to respect national legal systems.And that is what this report is about, to respect the national legal system.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: “blue card” response.- You have indeed imagined a few safeguards in your report, in particular the reserve of national public order.The problem, you see, is that I know very well how the European Union works.At first, she is satisfied with a moderate text and then after several years, we will be explained that more integration is needed and your reservations, dear colleague, will jump.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: - Mr. president. Today we present a proposal for a Resolution plus an annex that is intended to fill a legal gap and provide detailed and very specific recommendations for the development of a Regulation that can fill this legal gap and can address cross-border recognition of adoptions. There is no doubt that families in Europe today move and, in many cases, these families have adopted children. In some countries there are no problems, but in others there are problems, because in order for there to be recognition between the adoptee and the adopter, it is necessary to establish, in some countries, an additional judicial procedure. This creates instability in families and this goes against all the rights of the child and against the Hague Convention itself. Therefore, what is being asked here, I believe that with great success - and our rapporteur Tadeusz Zwiefka, has been, I believe, a great push so that this can see the light - is a clear legal framework that provides legal certainty, to provide the children's families with a stable family. And for that, minimum standards are proposed for adoption, greater cooperation is proposed, it is also proposed that the Hague Convention be respected, because everyone has signed it, but then there are problems in the execution. And finally, that this cross-border recognition of adoptions be automatic.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: -  Mister President!(The speaker speaks without a microphone.) ... that's why.Accordingly, the Commission's proposal and, above all, the work done by Mr Zwiefka as rapporteur must be expressly recognized.As the European Union, we must be a union of citizens.This also means removing unnecessary bureaucratic hurdles due to a lack of cooperation between national authorities.It is about making adoptions as easy as possible for reasons of child welfare and about removing all these hurdles accordingly.However, I would also like to point out that we should have arrived in 2017, and therefore point out once again that we as the European Parliament should finally ensure that lesbian and gay couples across Europe have equal rights in this regard.Again: for the best interests of the child.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, we are dealing with the cross-border aspects of adoption. I would first like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and express his full support. There are currently no European provisions for the recognition of national adoption decisions. This creates significant problems for European families who have moved to another Member State after adopting a child. Even as a doctor, I am convinced that the family environment creates the best possible conditions for the healthy development of the child and that any other environment can never fully replace his family. The bond that is created by adoption fully replaces the family relationship from a legal, psychological and social point of view. I hope that we will be able to remove obstacles to the cross-border aspects of adoption and, at the same time, to reduce the number of children dependent on education in state institutions.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: –  Mr President, too many children in Europe are deprived of a family due to bureaucracy, and too often children live in a judicial limbo in which their rights are not recognised throughout the EU. And that is why I fully support your report, Tadeusz, calling for mutual recognition and common standards for adoption. We have to address fragmentation and hurdles in the EU and increase judicial cooperation between the Member States, including through the European e-Justice portal. We need common minimum standards to enable Member States to exchange good practices without prejudice to national laws on adoption.  That is important. Adoption procedures will remain a national competence as much as family laws, but too many families cannot fully enjoy the freedom of movement of the European Union, and I support the proposal for a regulation on automatic mutual recognition of cross-border adoption orders, to ensure that the rights of adopted children are recognised and respected across the EU. As a co-Chair of the Intergroup on Children’s Rights in this Parliament, I am committed to make sure that the best interests of the child are recognised in all the adoption procedures.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the subject of adoptions has become an increasingly important issue as the mobility of people has increased. The report comes with a solution proposing the development of common minimum standards for adoptions. Even if they are considered rather good practice guidelines, all parties acknowledge that any adoption decision must be made exclusively in the best interests of the child and analyzed on the basis of individual characteristics. The report stipulates that, at European level, biological parents should be given the right to use all legal remedies before adoption proceedings can begin. In this way, some problems between Member States or even with third countries could be treated more transparently and measures would be taken to protect children. In these circumstances, cases such as those of the Barbu family in the United Kingdom or the Bugnariu family in a third country such as Norway will be dealt with more clearly, all the more so as the report indicates the need for the relevant consular authorities to be kept informed. on any proposed adoption decision in respect of a child who is a national of another Member State, but most importantly, the rights of the child will be protected.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, in the Petitions Committee of this Parliament we have received over three hundred petitions from individuals these years, from people who suffered problems with the adoption of minors, and in many cases just because a country does not recognize the adoption ruled by a courtor an administration from another country.For this reason, today we are happy to approve this Resolution that will require the Council to have a necessary legal tool.But, nevertheless, I also miss that we do not talk about the new family models that exist and that also cannot be hidden.I miss the courage to talk about adoptions by same-sex couples or by single people, for example.Ultimately, this is about moving forward and cementing a Europe of civil and social rights.Not, of course, of borders, bureaucracies or discrimination.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I very much welcome this report.The issue of cross-border adoption has been debated in the European Union for many years.I remember the debate in 2009, when the Czech Republic held the EU presidency, and at that time we had a debate on whether to amend one European law, one European adoption or, on the contrary, to advance the principle of mutual recognition.I think it is right that, in the end, the idea of mutual recognition has prevailed, which, in principle, does not strengthen the principle of European integration of family law, but, on the contrary, believes that individual states are able to adopt adoptions correctly within their jurisdiction.So I very much welcome the idea, it is, in my view, a compromise between those who want to make the cross-border aspects of adoption more effective, on the one hand, and those who do not want a single European family law.That correction is correct, and I congratulate the rapporteur and I hope that it will work in practice.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the best interests of the child are inherent in respect for their fundamental rights, of which one can only have real knowledge if one is able to reverse the perspective by changing the angle of view from adult to child. Facilitating this capacity is the task of institutions and all social actors, primarily the family. In international adoptions - which are a meeting of affections, but also of deeply different cultures - the protective family nucleus develops with a trilateral relationship: minor, adoptive and biological parent, with peculiar elements of extraneousness typical of private international law. In cross-border adoption, there are also greater legal uncertainties, mainly due to the different national recognition procedures and the divergence of guiding principles. The only remedy and primary point of reference for any cross-border adoption procedure therefore remains the substantial and non-formal compliance with Article 21 of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). - Mr President, the need to have children from different families is often met through the adoption of children from countries other than the country of the parents. Because every child has the right to live in an environment of love, affection and care, international adoption should be governed by rules that provide a minimum and are applied, if possible, by all countries of the European Union. The formal procedures of this case are not the predominant element. The key is to enable the child to grow up in a balanced and harmonious way and that is why adoptive families must show the necessary seriousness and the necessary respect for the child. Finally, I would like to point out that, in order for a child to grow up properly and not have psychological problems, he must grow up according to the laws of nature, with both parents, with both mother and father, and not be an adoption a child means of satisfying morbid expediencies and various illicit obsessions.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, giving priority to the interests of the child may be found in international law and in Member States’ law, and to that end it is necessary to consider two things: that these interests be properly translated into the procedural rules, because they should not be unnecessarily bureaucratic and lengthy; and also how they are applied.  That is why I am in favour of doing much more in conjunction with the Member States, for instance in the field of training of judges and professionals. The Commission will consider adding this as a new topic amongst other topics: where we train judges on victims’ rights, procedural safeguards for children, Brussels IIA, etc., this could also be covered. So this is my commitment to you from today’s discussion.  On the new legislation: family law is the domain of the Member States. We must be very careful here because these are emotional and sensitive topics; unanimity is required for a very good reason. So we will consider this call for legislation, but, as I said before, it must be evidence-based, there must be a test of whether this is a severe pan-European problem; whether there is strong demand from the Member States that we have a European solution; and the third important thing is whether the European Union has any legal competence to regulate on this.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka
text: rapporteur. - Mr Chairman! Shortly: I would like to sincerely thank all my colleagues who took the floor during today's debate, showing unequivocal support for such an approach to adoption procedures. Extremely important procedures, because we are talking about our children, about our future. Guaranteeing the child's well-being and its proper development is our absolute duty and priority. With all due respect to the provisions of the 1993 Hague Convention on the International Adoption of Children, it only deals with international adoptions. The report that we will be voting on in our House today talks about the recognition of national adoption orders, and that is a fundamental difference. We have no regulations in this area. Hence my proposal, which has been supported very broadly in today's debate and meets the expectations of parents, that their moving to another Member State should not complicate their lives when they are accompanied by adopted children. Many thanks to all those who worked with me on this report. It is not difficult to imagine how many different points could be addressed in such a report, but thank you for the fact that colleagues wanted to focus on the work in the area that I made clear at the beginning, that we did not throw in this report issues that cannot be addressed. accommodate in it. Thank you very much once again for the debate and for the promise from the Commission that we will prepare further regulations that will make life easier for our families.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 2 February 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - Investing in children is an investment in the future of our society, and their upbringing and education in decent and safe conditions must be permanently in everyone's attention, no matter where they are. In this context, we are talking about cross-border adoptions and the best interests of the child in such situations. Child protection is a priority in any situation, and in the case of cross-border adoptions there are a number of factors that must be taken into account to ensure the protection of children's interests. I support the importance of developing common minimum standards for adoptions, but also the need for better cooperation on civil justice in the field of adoptions. As there is no mandatory framework at European level for the recognition of adoption judgments given following a national procedure, legislative action is needed so that the right of European citizens to family life and free movement is permanently respected. The Commission and the Council must identify mechanisms to ensure the protection of the interests of children, European citizens, and when they live outside the European Union. It is extremely important that, in such situations, children have the opportunity to keep in touch with the cultural background, to learn and use their mother tongue.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing - The process related to the adoption or adoption of a child is not easy. The court decides on its outcome on the basis of the applicants' proposal. In the case of a positive result, adoptive parents have the same responsibilities, rights and obligations in raising children as biological parents. However, misunderstandings can arise when traveling or moving with such children to other countries. At present, unfortunately, there is no international or common European framework to ensure automatic recognition of national adoption decisions. No binding regulations will result. Rather, it is a matter of drawing up recommendations and best practices according to which such families, for example when moving to another country within the European Union, would not have to apply for recognition of an already issued domestic decision. This would remove some administrative barriers and strengthen the protection of the rights of children as well as their parents. It would make their lives easier and, at least in this area, they would be protected from possible further stressful situations.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. - In the matter of adoptions, the obstacles that stand in the way of the many cross-border cases affecting thousands of families are still too numerous. With the report by my colleague Zwiefka, measures are on the table that many European citizens have been waiting for for some time. I appreciate the effort made to suggest homogeneous and comprehensive proposals: I also believe that introducing a general regulation can really be a very effective tool. In particular, I would like to highlight the provision of common minimum standards for adoptions, based in particular on the belief that every adoption measure is issued purely in the interest of the child, and is evaluated on the basis of the specific characteristics of each case. The exchange of information between the competent consular authorities regarding the adoption of a child having the nationality of another Member State would already be a concrete step forward and immediately applicable, and I hope that the Commission, starting from some of the suggested examples, can propose quick and effective rules.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. - Compliance with Art. 21 of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child should form the basis of all procedures, actions and strategies for cross-border adoptions. In this context, citizens' access to full information on the legal and procedural aspects of national adoption in the Member States should be improved, which would facilitate international adoption, thereby increasing the number of adopted children. I agree that the e-Justice Portal could be the right place to look for such information. I believe that the European Commission should analyze complaints about cross-border adoptions without parental consent. Such cases should not be the case. When the child put up for adoption is a national of another Member State, the issuance of any decision should be preceded by consultations with the consular authorities of that country and the child's family residing there. European ombudsmen for children should be encouraged to cooperate and coordinate more closely within the framework of the European Network of Ombudspersons for Children. Such actions could include participation in EU-funded projects in the field of judicial training.

name: Julia Pitera (PPE)
text: in writing. - There is currently no mechanism in the European Union to regulate the automatic recognition of national adoption orders issued in the Member States. Complications can therefore arise when a child is adopted in the national system and the parents then decide to move to another Member State. Then such families may be obliged to undergo additional, special adoption recognition procedures in another Member State or even to re-adopt the child. And if the adoption is not recognized, it means that the parents will encounter obstacles in exercising parental responsibility. For example, they will not be able to enroll their children in school or agree to have an operation if a child becomes ill. Legal uncertainty in this area can therefore constitute a significant obstacle to the free movement of families. Therefore, I believe that recognition of domestic adoptions should be automatic, unless such recognition would be contrary to the public policy of the Member State in question or the Member State in which the adoption took place would not have jurisdiction. These two exceptions should be kept. They are also included in the legislative proposal. Therefore, I would like to unequivocally support the text proposed by MP Zwiefka.

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: In written form. - Ladies and gentlemen, there are many problems in the field of cross-border adoptions that affect many families and the interests of their children. I will focus on three of them. Firstly, and most importantly, I call on the European Commission to take the necessary measures to stop the vicious practice of adopting children without the permission of their biological parents in the European Union. We have many such cases in the UK that have become a business. I hope that the relevant changes will be made so that this happens only in extreme cases and for the exclusive protection of the best interests of the child. Secondly, we must encourage cooperation and the exchange of information, both between the courts dealing with adoption and between the social services and the national administrations of the Member States. Thirdly, in the case of cross-border adoptions, I would like to emphasize the need to respect cultural and social traditions according to the child's origin. Because it is in the best interest of the child to remain in the circle of his family, even if he is not in the child's usual place of residence. I support the proposal to introduce a common form for the recognition of these cross-border adoptions, as this will facilitate and save parents money. Thank you for your attention!

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF)
text: signed up. - I would like to emphasize that the field of family law at national level, and therefore adoption, is a matter for the Member States. However, when people decide to move to another Member State of the Union, there are difficulties in recognizing and resolving the legal situation of these people. However, I do not understand why we need to create new legislation, to impose new rules, instead of using the levers we already have, in order to get Member States to reach a uniform approach to adoptions. On the one hand, the training of national officials and judges involved in adoptions, the exchange of experience and the improvement of cooperation between them must be supported. On the other hand, Member States should be encouraged to avoid unnecessary bureaucracy in the field of adoptions. Let us not forget that what must prevail is the best interests of the child. In each of our countries there are enough abandoned children. It is important that each Member State facilitates national procedures so that these children can fully enjoy all rights, and first and foremost, the right to have a family.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: signed up. - Every child in the world has the right to a family and an environment in which to be loved and to receive the education necessary for adult life. That is why I believe that the European institutions have a moral responsibility to protect the rights of every family, and I am glad that Parliament is the first to propose a set of measures for those who have adopted children and want to enjoy the freedom to settle in another state. than the original one. In the context of an ever-increasing number of international couples and families, Community law must adapt to new realities and provide every family in Europe with the guarantee that their rights will be recognized and respected by the authorities in all Member States. At the same time, it is unfortunate that the European executive has not yet responded to the 2011 EP request to take steps to regulate cross-border adoption issues. This is not just about defending principles, but also about protecting the rights of all parents and children in the European Union, wherever they may be, in concrete situations.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: in writing. - The topic we are talking about today is very important and relates to aspects that affect a child's whole life. With this in mind, we must not forget that in the field of adoption, it is very important to take all decisions for the welfare of the child, respecting the fundamental rights of the child and the parents. The purpose of adoption is not to give adults the right to a child, but to provide the child with a stable environment in which to grow harmoniously, surrounded by care and love. Let us not forget that cross-border adoption should only take place as a last resort, as it permanently severes the child's ties with his or her country of origin. Legislation should strike a balance between the rights of the adopted child to know his or her identity and the rights of the biological parents. Under no circumstances can a child be taken away from his or her parents and placed in cross-border adoption because of parental poverty. The relevant competent authorities of the Member States should not recognize cases where the material conditions of the biological parents constitute an exceptional ground and reason for depriving them of their parental authority and for placing the child for adoption. This is unacceptable and must be clearly defined in the legislation. Biological parents should also be able to seek full redress to resolve a negative decision for them. And in the case of adoption, the child should end up in a full family that includes both mother and father.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - There are currently no binding European frameworks for the recognition of cross-border adoptions. The existing Hague Convention only provides for a system of administrative cooperation when adoptive parents and children do not reside in the same country. Both the right of European citizens to family life and the right to free movement are at the top of the priorities of the European People's Party and the Slovenian Democratic Party. I am strongly in favor of the EU providing a clear legal framework that would make life easier for many families. It seems unacceptable to me that parents who move abroad, for example, should once again prove their custody of their children, which can happen when enrolling in school or arranging health insurance. The European Certificate of Adoption is therefore a good proposal that would save many families unnecessary bureaucratic procedures. We have heard many debates in Parliament on the issue of Member States' subsidiarity in the field of cross-border adoptions. At the same time, it is important to know that the legislation of the Member States in the field of family law will still be respected. Legislation could prevent unnecessary complications for many families, as well as ensure that the adopted child's right to a stable legal position is respected. That is how we will act for the good of the children.
