name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: - Madam President!I would like to point out that this report is in fact a kind of appeal: an appeal to combat doping, an appeal for pure sport, but also an appeal to lower various taxes.And I want to emphasize here that - what is crucial - it is aimed primarily at children and those who practice mass sport.For this reason, I have supported this report.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, given my sporting background I supported this report in the light of its comprehensive evaluation of sporting policy within the European Union. Transcending all social spheres, I firmly believe that sporting initiatives could serve as a vital vehicle for social inclusion, sporting involvement in growth, employment and indeed society as a whole. However in recent times we have borne witness to a growing trend of corruption within the sporting climate. The series of recent high-level corruption cases on both the European and international stage have made it clear that transparency and greater regulation and cohesion in sporting policy must now define our path. Sport reflects society, and we must safeguard this sector for the benefit of generations to come.   Molaim an tUasal Takkula as an jab atá déanta aige.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Takula's report examines the broad social, economic, educational and health benefits of sport in the Union and the current challenges. Calls for multi-level action to promote good governance, fight corruption, while respecting the independence of sports organizations. Overall, the direction given by the final compromise is positive and the fact that grassroots sport plays a key role in social cohesion and the fight against radicalization, and that volunteering in sport is of great importance, must be supported. There is a need for more efficient use of European Union funds for sport. I also believe that it is necessary, and even mandatory, to reduce the administrative burden for local sports organizations. However, I voted against the report because I am against the paragraph which obliges national sports federations to use the Union flag and symbol, together with the relevant national flags and symbols, when holding international sporting events. This is much more federalism than I can accept. I consider myself a defender of the national interests in the Union, who must work together in certain policies for the common good and good neighborly relations, but I will always uphold the inviolability of the flag, symbols and national traditions.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I have finally stayed behind this report, so I want to explain why.By no means do I want to oppose sport, I am aware of how important this aspect of human life is, but I wonder to what extent the issue of sport is to be addressed by the EU and to what extent it is not exactly the subject of individual nation states.Nevertheless, there are things in the report that I have finally refrained from.For example, the effort to enforce specialized prosecutors 'offices to deal with sports crimes, I consider this to be a really strange thing, I do not know why we should have specialized prosecutors' offices, especially for this type of crime.In small states, on the other hand, this will lead to such offices probably not having much work and, on the contrary, their expertise would rather decrease.So sport certainly is, but the question is how much to receive such reports at EU level.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: –  Madam President, from my point of view of the main task of sport is to propagate a healthy lifestyle among young people. Sports make an important contribution to social values such as tolerance, solidarity, peace, respect for human rights, and understanding among nations and cultures. Recent corruption scandals have tarnished the image of sport, raising questions about the need for structural reforms of sports governing bodies and organisations. We need a zero tolerance policy for corruption and other types of crime in sports. Fighting corruption in sport requires transnational efforts and cooperation among all stakeholders, including public authorities, law enforcement agencies, the sport industry, athletes and supporters.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I have decided to support the European Parliament's resolution on an integrated approach to sport policy because, like my colleague Dzhambazki, I see them as a call to promote sport and also to protect sport from abuse, from business.It's an appeal to the fair play aspect.Professional sports and far from not only football but also other sports face negative phenomena, such as corruption, influencing the results of matches, doping, poor management of sports clubs or the abuse of athletes, such as third party ownership of players.I agree with my colleague Pospíšil that it is necessary to consider what legislative instruments we will use, but in any case we must fight against these phenomena in order to maintain a positive image of professional and amateur competitions so that sport remains a sport, especially fair play.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: –  Madam President, sport is surely the supreme example of a non-political, non-state activity, the ideal of a civil society. A sporting club or association exists for no higher purpose than to give mutual pleasure to its members and supporters. Nobody is forced to join, people stay only if they want to. So why do we need to have a sport policy? How have we got to the point where politicians need to get their hands on something that ought to lie outside the purview of government? Having a sport policy always struck me as a sign of an insecure dictatorship. It was the kind of thing that the Comecon states used to do in the Cold War, to treat sporting success as a symbol of national virility. Surely we in advanced democracies should hold ourselves to a higher standard.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, I naturally voted in favor of this report. The EU has limited competence in the field of sport, and it is in the context of this report. Given what the EU's competences are. Some members seemed to have read the report and some did not. Therefore, I do not want to interfere with all the explanations of vote that have been gone through here today. So much for saying that when the flag issue came up here and I realized that, as a result, many in the ECR Group voted against it not being a matter of binding matters but of recommendations. I myself opposed that idea, but this is a recommendation, and since it is a recommendation, it does not bind anyone. You can put its flag even inside the shirt or leave it on altogether. As for the freedom of the independent states to decide again. How civilized are we? Just recently, Hannan quit. I know that when the UK goes to the Olympics, there is Team GB, and when football is played, Wales, Scotland, England and Northern Ireland are separately. While rugby is played, there is Ireland, where Northern Ireland, Wales, Scotland and England are separately. It can be said that even now we are taking this diversity into account. We are talking about the general importance of sport to move people and fight the problems and diseases we have in Europe and to guarantee the well-being of our citizens across different borders.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union must be an opportunity for the citizens and not an obstacle. The situation of a family with adopted children who decides to move abroad can turn into a bureaucratic nightmare: it could even happen that the adoption process is not recognized, it could be necessary to start new practices - it would be like asking, in practice, to a child to be reborn. And if the second country's assessment were different, what would happen? Paradoxical situations would be created. I voted in favor of this report because it makes it clear that adoption is not a couple's right to become parents but a child's right to live in a stable, loving and caring environment. It is understandable that the legal systems of the Member States are different, but in compliance with the principle of subsidiarity, action is needed. The first step could be the adoption of a regulation for the automatic recognition of adoption measures in member countries.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, with my vote, I supported the report on the proposal for a Council regulation on cross-border aspects of adoption, which proposes the introduction of automatic recognition of national adoption decisions issued in one Member State by another.Such a rule will allow the recognition of a decision of a court or other competent authority on adoption issued in another Member State.However, it in no way interferes with national adoption rules.I consider it important to state this as the real reason why I supported this draft report.I personally do not agree that children should be given for adoption to registered partners, but I am convinced that this draft report is not about this decision and does not interfere with national legislation, which fully decides on the conditions of adoption within its competence.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: –  Madam President, the adoption of children is a very important and sensitive task for our societies, and is especially so for Latvia. It is a shame that a lot of children still live in special state institutions, not in their families. States should take all decisions in adoption matters with the best interests of the child in mind, and with respect for his or her fundamental rights, while always taking into account the specific circumstances of the particular case. The child should always be given the opportunity to be heard without pressure and express his or her view on the adoption process, taking into account his or her age. No decision on adoption should be taken before the biological parents have been heard. I am convinced that the interests of the children have to be taken in consideration as the only main criterion. I voted in favour, of course.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I abstained on my report by my colleague, Zvefka, because I do not think that the Union needs to intervene in areas that fall within the sovereignty of the Member States. The choice of the strongest legal argument for harmonization of legislation - the regulation on a specific topic - is also evidence of interference in the internal policies of the Member States of the Union. At the same time, I support the strengthening of judicial cooperation in the field of adoptions, because it is our moral duty to provide the maximum opportunity to protect one of the most vulnerable groups in society. The family is the basis of a society. It is for this reason that we must be able to find the balance so that, at the same time, we protect the rights of the family and do not take away the powers of the Member States from policies based on cultural and historical factors and traditions.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: - Adoption must be in the best interests of the child.Member States define the law when this interest is met.If the European Union orders states to automatically recognize adoptions that are not allowed by their own laws, it will be a gross interference with their exclusive powers in the field of family law.As a result of such an intervention, the best interests of the child for the Union as a whole will be defined by the Member State with the most liberal laws.In other countries, a schizophrenic situation will arise and their courts will have to deal with discriminatory lawsuits.The rapporteur's efforts to define minimum standards for adoption are commendable.However, it should have stopped where Member States' views on family and child adoption differ.Therefore, I could not support this report.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: –  Madam President, now here is a subject with an apparently cross-border aspect. Adoptions do take place across national borders, and it seems sensible to have a framework. Of course, immediately one runs up against the fact that most cross-border adoptions are not limited to EU Member States. There is a lot of adoption that takes place from outside the EU. And here’s the good news: it is regulated by an international framework; it is regulated by the Hague Convention of 1993. So why do we need additional EU regulation that applies narrowly only to one part of the world? I suppose it is conceivable that there are some gaps that need to be filled in. But again countries could surely opt in on a bilateral or multilateral basis without needing to involve the entire bureaucracy of the European Union? I have said it before and I’ll say it again: international cooperation beats supranational government every time.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: –  Madam President, a European regulation where the rights of the child are prioritised should be welcomed. However this report calls for measures that we should absolutely reject. In the name of convenience and harmonisation of documents, children would be at the risk of being trafficked across borders. Already some Member States have seen a dramatic rise in the number of children being taken into care away from their biological parents. Research into abuse consistently shows that natural parents are the ones least likely to abuse their children.  We cannot put children at risk by loosening the strict adoption procedures in place, by imposing a poor, one-size-fits-all European regulation. A child needs both father and mother to flourish. Let us invest in supporting that most important family unit, helping biological parents raise their children even in difficult circumstances.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to comment on the vote on this item. Banana production is an important part of the agricultural production of some EU Member States and creates a significant number of jobs in this area. That is why efforts must also be made to maintain European banana production. I therefore voted in favor of the report on the proposal for a regulation amending the regulation implementing the bilateral safeguard clause and the stabilization mechanism for bananas between the EU, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, as well as the Central African countries, on the other. Given the extension of the preferential tariffs for trade in bananas to Ecuador as well, I welcome the extension of the safeguard clause and the stabilization mechanism to Ecuador as well. I also agree with the obligation to oblige the Commission to monitor compliance with the established volume of banana imports and to inform the European Parliament in the event of a serious disturbance of this market.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: –  Madam President, it is curious, isn’t it, that the European Union has trade restrictions on bananas. It is not exactly as though there is a domestic banana industry in the European Union that requires protection. A friend of mine in Cornwall did once show me banana tree in his garden, but I don’t think it was on a scale that was of significant mercantile importance.  The reason we have these restrictions is well-intentioned. We think we are sticking up for largely former French and British colonies in the Caribbean, the ones that produce the little squashy bananas, if I can put it that way, rather than the big long straight ones. But we’re not doing those territories any favours. We are keeping them in a sense of dependency, we are preventing them from expanding into other areas, diversifying their economies and competing in world markets.  And as a price for doing this, we are slightly pushing up prices in Europe, taking a little bit of money out of the pockets of our consumers which would otherwise be spent on stimulating the economy at home. So everybody ends up being a loser from these restrictions. It would be easier by far to have free trade rather than these rules, which are bananas.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: –  Madam President, the European Union Common Fisheries Policy has incurred much criticism, and I believe rightly so. Fish stocks, due to overfishing, are now in many instances at critically low levels. Not content, though, with inflicting this ecological damage on waters surrounding the British Isles, the North Atlantic and the Mediterranean, the European Union has established arrangements to conduct the same activities in the waters beyond its jurisdiction.  The proposed regulation would establish a new authorisation framework and extend the scope of the authorisation system to all European Union fishing activities outside European Union waters. But when the United Nations remarks that the European Union practice is endangering 1.5 million African jobs, and when Greenpeace and the United Nations are able to identify the source of the overfishing issue as being the European Union, I’m very sorry, I was just unable to support the motion.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, as a new member of the Committee on Fisheries, I was pleased to vote in favour of this report, which calls for a clarification on licensing rules for EU vessels fishing outside EU waters. This regulation would also extend the current licensing system to include private agreements between EU companies and third countries.  The current regulation dates back to 2008 and the update of the legislation would apply to all EU vessels fishing outside EU waters and to third—country vessels fishing in EU waters. This is extremely relevant for Ireland as it clarifies certain rules which would impact on our fishermen, who are such hard workers but have been affected greatly by EU legislation. Providing more clarifying eligibility criteria for third—country vessels would help Irish fishermen as it would ensure that those who do want to fish in our waters are fully and properly licensed.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the common fisheries policy is perhaps the policy which has had the worst impact on your reference production sector. Of course, great results have been achieved from an environmental, sustainability and fish restocking point of view, but fishermen have seen the rules and regulations to be respected multiply and have had to undertake costly renovations. They did all this in order to continue their business, in compliance with the principles imposed by Brussels. The external dimension of fishing is another sore point. It is certainly a good thing that the European Union fulfills its responsibilities as a flag state, but it would be the case that the Union also fulfills its responsibilities for the protection of fishing vessels which fish in conditions of great insecurity and which are exposed to great risks. I want to mention again the case of Sicilian fishermen who risk their lives in conflicts with the police of neighboring countries, in particular Libya. This is what we call the fish war, because it involves kidnappings and shootings, and this is also what the European Union must take on and take care of.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I supported this resolution, I think it is necessary to maintain above-standard relations with Georgia, as well as with other allies in the framework of the Eastern Partnership.I will not repeat here what the visa-free regime brings to the future, ie.strengthening economic and other aspects.For me personally, the most important aspect is geopolitical, ie.A country in Russia's immediate neighborhood, which is more or less permanently threatened by Russia, finds a partner in the EU, and with this gesture on the way we say that we care about Georgia and that we consider Georgia as our partner.So the geopolitical level is more important to me than that visa-free travel will lead to a deepening of mutual relations, economic benefits on both sides, etc. This is necessary for me if we do not want the countries around Russia to gradually continue to fall under the influence of this country..

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Madam President, unfortunately I have not been able to speak on this point in a proper debate, which is why I am at least using this institute. I want to say that I consider it important that the European Parliament addresses the human rights agenda in other countries outside the European territories, and that this is particularly important for countries where there is strong economic support. We make it clear on the part of the EU that these countries should respect fundamental human rights and also respect the basic principles of the constitution and, say, the rule of law, if at all possible. That is why I supported this resolution, it is good that we are drawing attention to both Gabon and Congo that the presidents there are violating their constitutions, that they are not democratic, that the rights of the opposition, the rights of public speech, etc. are being suppressed. if the situation in these countries does not improve, they should reduce economic aid to this area, to this region of Africa.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen!I would like to point out that we started working on the Erasmus + report with opinions that emerged questioning the program as such.Today, also at this moment, many young people are sitting in this room, so I would like to make it clear that we are finishing work on the report with a 40% increase in funding for scholarship programs.This is a very important success.At the same time, I would like to add that at the same time we reduced the so-calledmaturing liabilities, which improved the implementation of the program and positively influences the opinions that appear about it at present.I would like to thank everyone very much for the work on this report, which was quite lengthy and accompanied at the same time the 2014 and then 2015 budget implementation reports.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Madam President, I have a very contrary view and that is because I see the Erasmus project as one of the many European Union sacred cows. It is directed at young people and it is focused solely on developing and encouraging the European Union project. For the period 2014-2020, as we have just heard, Erasmus has seen its project budget increase by 40%. I recognise that propaganda comes at a cost, and this is recognised by the European Union when influencing young people as to the so-called ‘merits’, and I put merits in quotation marks, of the European Union federalist project.  But a country doesn’t need to be a member of the European Union to be part of the Erasmus project, and as an internationalist I see the cultural and educational experience that should be available to all within the educational sector irrespective of European Union borders. It should not be conditioned, it should not be directed, and it should not be focused just on the European Union. And it certainly should not be controlled by the European Union. It is a big wide world out there, and I want to see more done with Australia and Asia.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I have always advocated strongly for initiatives such as Erasmus +, and in recent years I have observed its true potential being realised for Irish and European citizens alike. I therefore supported this report, due to the rapporteur’s balanced reassessment of the inter—relationship between education and innovation. In line with the principle of lifelong learning, the future of the EU may henceforth be bolstered by teams of creativity, competence and entrepreneurship.  The budget increase towards this scheme reaffirms the high political and economic value of Erasmus +, and I hope to see this scheme continue to grow from strength to strength, and especially be availed of by more Irish people to improve their language skills, which need improving from an Irish context, and also the Erasmus + aspect which now encompasses sport. I know that one body that was involved with it, the Leinster GAA Council, are hoping to avail of that. That would be a wonderful fillip and a great way of bringing Europe closer to EU citizens.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favor of the report on the implementation of the Erasmus + program, which we have been working on for a long time and have reached some good compromises. Erasmus + is the European Union's most successful and emblematic program and its continuation and future existence should be encouraged and supported. However, I would like to emphasize that there are also things in the report that were agreed without my participation. And one of them concerns the so-called the Commission's refugee policy, which is strongly praised against my convictions. I have repeatedly expressed my opinion in this regard and I will not fail to do so now. The integration of migrants from the last migrant crisis will not happen in the way that is proposed and praised in the report. And the European Commission certainly does not offer any good alternative or solution to the problem.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President. Erasmus + is one of the most successful EU programmes. It is a major EU tool to support activities in the fields of education, training, youth and sport, giving the opportunity to more than 4 million Europeans to study, train and volunteer in another country. At a time of particular crisis with regard to the fundamental values of the European Union, the Erasmus+ instrument can provide a fundamental opportunity to promote integration, understanding and solidarity among young people. It is very important because they will be the next generation of Europeans. They will be active society members, decision makers, voters and parents. This programme is working well, but the European Parliament has made some recommendations on how to improve its performance. In my point of view we should find more resources for this programme, for the next period until 2027. Of course, I voted in favour.

text: This concludes the explanations of vote.
